Why can't they train it in their own home? When I make an app, I personally use it, not just as beta testing but I use it on my primary devices for months, encountering bugs, perfecting it, then I give it to people in my close circle to beta test, before making it public. I don't sell these products, they are open source and I can still do it, why can't companies? I can imagine, that the training wont be vast with say 20 people training it while they use it vs millions (or honestly a few thousand in this case), but its a starting point. The product can be at least Beta, and not in Alpha as most of these products are.

Warning: X1 was started in Norway. They moved just before "exit wealth" tax was introduced. Meaning they avoid wealth tax in the future. That is not the issue, in this case. The issue is the stuff said here AND that I think X1 makers will try to go on the stock market before their product is fully realized. This, if done "correctly", would massively increase share price and give an exit strategy for owners and primary investors, aka make them rich. If 1% wealth tax is too much to pay in Norway. It goes without saying that the plan does not include expected boost and growth of revenue. This is a hype stock potential, I think. The product is not the focus. The focus is hype to increase future IPO interest. Too the MOON!   Note: This is my personal view of this and such risk.

I work at a certain robotics company (not allowed to say) and this is standard. When i was on the floor and I saw one of the guy's with investors walking through talking about what they want to get to in order to make it public. They want 10's of thousands of hours, many more of training data before its public. We currently are very very far away from that.  I think it is possible but it requires a long term investment. The promise i really don't think is empty. But its hard. Now I will say for a household setting that is kind of wild to me because we try to work in a retail or warehouse setting. But those area's can be redesigned to look very similar and homogenous. The household setting thing seems way too chaotic for me to understand how you could pull that off.

Humanoid robots always make me smile with a touch of pity. They remind me of the early attempts to build flying machines with flapping wings that imitated birds - and usually crashed before even taking off. Itâ€™s exactly the same situation - humanoid robots are simply stupid. We already have plenty of â€œrobotsâ€ in our homes that look nothing like humans, and thatâ€™s precisely why they work so well. Itâ€™s as if someone tried to build a washing machine that mimics people scrubbing clothes in a river, or a vacuum cleaner with arms sweeping the floor, not to mention a dishwasher that uses a sponge and dish soap and then dries the plates with a cloth. Yes - I understand the idea is to make a home assistant with broader functionality than any of the devices I mentioned, but it would probably be far more efficient, stable, and faster if it moved on wheels and had, instead of a five-fingered hand, an arm with a suction surface for handling small and delicate objects, plus grippers for heavier ones. If people thought like the creators of these robots, weâ€™d still be wearing hand-sewn clothes, because sewing machines use two spools of thread in a way completely different from how humans sew with a needle and thread.

It isn't even just self driving with Tesla - it is the whole product. The model of selling something on hype, taking deposits and delivering ... something ... eventually ... is the business model that they created. How many Cybertruck deposits did they sit on for how long before shipping anything? How many Tesla Roadster deposits are still washing around their bank accounts today? Fake it before you make it has always been a thing in Silicon Valley (just ask Elizabeth Holmes springs to mind, but the concept of selling a non-workable demo goes all the way back to the 70s), so this is just the application of that to todays big thing that everyone wants to be first to market with. ğŸ¤·â€â™‚

Thatâ€™s the part most people miss. They let fear and skepticism cloud logic. Itâ€™s easy to call it marketing hype when you donâ€™t understand the cognitive process behind innovation. These robots have to learn in the wild in real homes with real human behavior not sterile labs. The early buyers arenâ€™t being fooled theyâ€™re helping shape the evolution of true autonomy. Fear always ridicules what it doesnâ€™t understand.

People need to understand that if nobody buys these humanoid robots early, theyâ€™ll never get finished. The only way to make them fully autonomous is by learning from real-world use. You canâ€™t perfect human-like intelligence in a lab homes, people, and daily life are the real training grounds. Buying them early isnâ€™t wasting money, itâ€™s contributing to the evolution of the technology itself.

People keep saying these humanoid robots are being sold â€œtoo early,â€ but thatâ€™s literally the only way theyâ€™ll ever get smarter. You canâ€™t train real-world autonomy in a lab or simulator homes and human environments are way too unpredictable. They need to be exposed to the chaos, the variables, the noise. Just like how self-driving cars learned from millions of real miles, humanoid robots have to learn from living in real homes. Selling early isnâ€™t marketing hype, itâ€™s a necessary phase of evolution. Without real data, theyâ€™ll never reach the level of true intelligence people expect. This person's perspective has nuances to it that people should take into consideration. This looks more like a remote control toy and anything actually useful. Even its robot mechanics are inferior than many other companies. Unitree's motion controlled robots moves way faster with higher accuracy and strength compared to this garbage.  Fully autonomous robots are still decades away, its not even close. At best we can have one that can pick up your laundry and put them into the washing machine and press the start button or app control the washing machine to start washing. To pick up and wash dishes? That's gonna take another decade. Even longer for cooking and other delicate stuffs. For basic cleaning, the current vacuum and mopping robots are still the more optimal and efficient choice. You don't need humanoid robots for everything. Self driving cars don't need robots, even cooking can be done by automatic cooking machines, probably built together with refrigerator so it can acquire ingredients from the fridge automatically, making the process more autonomous. Humanoid robots are better with transportation tasks, like picking up clothes, clearing the trash, or collecting mail and parcels etc. Or act as companions if it can be advance enough to play soccer or basketball with you, or have sex. I think our path forward is to have multiple different robots for different tasks. For a humanoid robot to be able to do every tasks effectively and replace all other robots, that might take half a century at least.

Hello Sir, I've been a long-time viewer of your excellent content and always thought my comments would get lost in the sea of messages. But, after gathering some courage, I'm finally reaching out in hopes of getting some personalized advice. From next year, I'll be starting college, and I need a reliable phone. This is going to be my very first phone ever, which makes the decision even more significant! My budget is strictly around â‚¹20,000 to â‚¹25,000, though I could potentially stretch it to â‚¹30,000 if there's an exceptional offer worth considering.  Here are my main requirements:  Performance: No high-end gaming or heavy video editing. Normal, everyday usage with occasional moderate use is fine. Most modern phones in this range seem to handle this well enough.  Camera: A good camera for everyday photos is important.  Storage: Decent storage performance (better than UFS 2.0).  Crucial Need: Seamless Multitasking: This is the most important factor. I have a Samsung Book 2 laptop (bought in 2024), and since I'm going for CSE in college (coding, projects, etc.), the ability to multitask effortlessly between my phone and laptop is a major priority.  I'm focused more on my laptop's performance than my phone's, which is why I've already invested heavily in upgrades for my laptop (a Samsung 990 EVO Plus 2TB SSD and 8GB Crucial RAM upgrade, totaling around â‚¹15,000â€”almost half my phone budget!). I know you might instinctively suggest a Samsung phone, and while they're good, I feel their models in the â‚¹20k-â‚¹30k range fall short compared to brands like Vivo or iQOO in terms of specs. For instance, the rumored S24 FE with its Exynos chip is a concern due to potential heating and lower Antutu scores compared to something like an iQOO Neo 10R or a Moto Edge Pro in the â‚¹25k range. I've also seen issues firsthand; my father's F55 started lagging within just six months. I'm looking for the perfect balance of performance, features, and crucially, that robust ecosystem connectivity for my college journey. Any guidance you could offer would be truly appreciated! Thank you so much for your time and all the amazing content you create. Best regards, A long-time viewer

I agree with most of your points. But I want to argue a little on the opposite side or at least raise some points so we can think about where we are going with this technology.  I think 1X Neo is different from the Rabbit and Humane pin, from a product definition point of view. People never asked for devices like Rabbit and Humane pin, and they can't replace phones since many functions of a phone requires a nice screen. Humanoid robot is something people have been dreamed about for decades if not hundreds of years. If it does what it promises, I want it. I can't say the same for the Rabbit and Humane pin. Even if they do well what they are advertised for, I don't see myself using them. But again, I am with you on how far Neo is from our expectations, or the expectation 1X is trying to sell.  I totally understand the privacy concern, especially when there may be a real person remotely controlling it. I would not want such a thing in my house, or at most limit it to a very small part of my house. And the limit has to be physical, not some virtual fence. On the flip side, Neo may help in a commercial or industrial world. Even if they are only remote controlled, the advantage is to reduce travel time of human. This thing can be planted or shipped to many locations where a human expert can't be at fast enough. But your question of why it has to be in a human shape is valid, because if I want a remote plumber to inspect or fix something, it may be even better for it to be small and with extendable cameras. The only advantage of a humanoid robot is it can fit into a world we designed for human, e.g. stairs, furnitures, even tools. Rather than have many specialized robot, a humanoid robot can take advantage of all the conveniences we already designed for human.  I don't like a company over promise on a product. However, I think the reality is that these new techs cost a lot of money to perfect. Unless there are investors that are willing to put their own money into such companies, they need some products to get some attention to the technology itself. I agree Neo is probably far from reality and very likely to fail, but deep down I want it to success. It is a similar feeling I had when I saw the DARPA Grand Challenge in 2004. I knew self driving is possible and we will have it after see that one team completed the course. 20 more years later, we are not completely there, but I think most people would agree it is possible and what's needed now is perfection, ethical and legal discussions. So for me, whether Neo will become a practical product or not is less important. The important thing is that companies feel they are close to create such a product. Similar type of robots are being designed and built in China as well. With AI advancing so fast in the last few years, having the intelligent required is reachable. But before Neo or similar products can be just another appliance in our homes, we definitely have to solve the privacy and safety concerns. That may still be 20 or 50 years from us.  Actually, for the remote control part of the task, I think it is quite valuable. Rather than a caretaker or nurse walking to each senior's room, they can in one place simply switch to different robots close to the patient or resident. It may not be able to do all the things a nurse can do in person, but checking and reminding an elderly to take medicine is very reasonable in VR. I hope such applications can bridge the gap now and our dreamed robot. I think your analogy of Tesla's self-driving strategy applies here.  Again, I enjoy your videos. Not only you shared the tech but made me think or dream.

I appreciate the mention of disabled people. I'm more interested in a remote-operated assistant so an agency can remotely fill in for an absent carer than in trusting an AI corporation to accommodate for my specific needs (which is absolutely not going to happen). I can't speak for other disabled people, but I certainly don't need it to have an able-shaped humanoid form-factor, a cute face or a pair of five-fingered hands. After all, I am privileged to have all of those already; they're wonderful, but they're not what get the job done.  Of course, even in a best-case scenario, it could never replace a carer who's there in the room. I'm obviously a huge proponent of remote working because, y'know, disabled, but that's not a job you can do without the rapport and mutual trust that comes from a single person who can solve problems in the moment. They'd also have to increase care budgets to the point that I can trust the technology and the substitute carer; without a bond of trust it needs to be worth their time to help me, and not worth the potential loss of the job to take advantage of my privacy or otherwise abuse or neglect me.   I'm not paranoid and I quite like people, but I'm eventually going to come across the rare bad egg and that rare bad egg could end my life very easily, and I say that as one of the harder-to-kill disabled people. After all, oversight can only go so far, and that involves living with even less privacy. Good pay isn't a sufficient solution either, and honestly my main motivation for better-paid carers is that they've more than earned it, but much of my life already relies on someone working just above minimum wage and I'm going to have trouble with that if they're not also a person I can trust.  AI, again, isn't a solution. They are not going to have my specific experiences in their training data, much less someone with even more complex issues than I do. We can't train assistance dogs in factories and even my actual human carers come to me having to learn everything about my specific needs over the course of months. Even as a fill-in, I'm not trusting an AI with my medication, and, again, I'm pretty privileged with the ability to see and operate a pill container for myself. If people are going to be reliant on this technology, there needs to be human involvement at every level; even if hell freezes over and AI is all it's cracked up to be a month from now, the LLM craze has destroyed understanding and trust in intelligent technology, both of which are necessary for disabled people to rely on technology.  Of course, the real danger is that these decisions end up being made for disabled people. It not always willingly that we use the technology available to us, and this may be no different. I would suggest a high level of caution when talking about this technology for that reason; if they decide to pivot to talking to our governments without our involvement, things could get very dangerous, very fast.  I can only speak for myself, but this sort of thing worries me.  Thank you for reading.

The thing is, companies have always had to do R&D for their products. Making something new always takes a lot of work up front. That means paying people to test the product under a variety of use cases and then sending it back to the engineers to work out the kinks that the testers find, and then back and forth until the product is ready for market. And when you're shooting for a really ambitious product maybe you do a scaled down version first that only requires testing more limited use cases and then if that product does well enough you can take what you learned developing it, as well as whatever money that it makes, and plow that into making the more fully-featured product.   Companies have just gotten way too comfortable offloading their product development onto consumers so that they can make their shareholders more short term profits.

Tesla full self driving is a great example of promise before product and glad you called out the games industry (preorders) as well - though this is now the case with pretty much all "living" software that improves over time. Some of this might be an indicator of a healthy/hopeful marketplace if there is SUCH an advantage to being an early implementor, but I can't help but be reminded of Google Glass, a promise which is only NOW, 11 years later, being fulfilled by a different product company using different strategies, marketing, and tech. Is it really that important to be the first failed product to introduce the marketplace to a concept only to fail the promise? Only venture capitalists can tell.

Come on now, they've been quite clear that what they're selling is both an experiment and a dream. The entire pitch is that you get a robot at a subsidised price ($20k is easily below cost) in exchange for your entire home life being used as training data for the real product. This is the only viable business model for getting that training data (robots need to be in homes somehow for this), and in the current tech ecosystem where the biggest companies on the planet are pirating copyrighted work and coercing their users into forking over their personal data with the threat of removing access to their social lives, an honest contract between two consenting parties is a breath of fresh air.

Exactly this pushback is why all these promises of humanoid robots being in many people's homes will not happen in the near or even medium future time.  Nobody wants to shell enough money for a cheap or decent used car, for a device with so many potentially awful outcomes.  Plus it simply won't have enough utility even if it does ALL the tasks they demonstrated, for $20k.  Not a chance almost anyone would pay that.  You could literally hire a maid to come to your house every week and do those chores and clean the home with expert precision, for years and years before it would have added up to $20k.  Imagine it turns the gas on the hob on and then just freezes until the house explodes...  Or any number of other seriously dangerous 'glitch' moments.  The Tesla comparison is a good one, which has itself been hard and arduous a challenge enough for their team to develop good models for that are now useful.  This robot will take decades to do these tasks reliably.

All they needed to do was refer to this as an Alpha model. Not a Beta product, but a product in Alpha testing. That's why it is still remote operated, rather than autonomous. I totally understand how this technology still requires remote operation as it is developing. I would presume that a person would be needed 100% initially, then the reliance begins to decrease as operations become part of the systems routine.   When I worked as an Autonomous Driving Trainer, we would sit in the car and let it drive us around for hours. Much of the time initially we would have to take over, note bugs, verify it's behaviors and so on. Each evening the data was sent to the Engineers who would use it to advance the programming, correct issues, etc.   This is likely going to be no different than putting autonomous vehicles on the road, where there need to be trainers present through the maturation process. Over time the trainers will be needed less and less.   None of that should be a surprise, but they do need to be far far more clear about that aspect of it's utility.

this is the problem with all humanoid robots - what are they going to do for you?  The humanoid form if a general form - you want to min / max - especially at cost.   Need to vacuum your house?  Get a roomba.   Need to cook?  Buy pre-made dinners.  Need to get a drink from the fridge - get up and get your own drink - seriously.   How lazy are you.    Need to do the dishes - we have dishwashers.  Laundry - well one day they might have a useful sorting device.  The point is - that the humanoid robot just serves no function that cant be better done by something else - carrying things and following you around is not a worth 20k.   The only obvious usecase that makes it worth it is companionship... and this doesnt just mean the kind we are all thinking of.    But seriously - it has no function worth even the cost of electricity and maintenance and until AI becomes sentient it never will.  We need to start having a serious conversation about CEOs and companies mismarketing their products - we had this with so many products that end up with billion dollar evaluations off of lies.   Remember Magic Leap... it doesnt matter if you label something as "demo" or whatever if you heavily imply - "this is what this is capable of" as the magic leap demo videos were followed up with and this is what people are playing in the office today.   Of course if they were it was something 100x less impressive.   And this is what Elon has done to build an empire - "you will be able to add your car to a robotaxi network - next year!" or "we will fly to mars" or "we will build 10k humanoid robots this year!"... everyones been taking notes - Jeff Bezo - "we will have a million people living in space at the end of the decade" or all the fusion reactors that will supposedly have fusion power to the grid in a couple of years but have shown nothing operational that would imply that they could.  Its all IMO scams... maybe one day the technology can get us there,  I have no doubt that we will be capable of producing self driving cars.  But you should not be allowed to sell a product that doesnt exist at least to public investors.   If you go out and say that your going to build 10,000 humanoid robots by the end of 2025 - you need to show that when you made that statement that you had the capability to do so and that those robots had some sort of utility worth buying... because it certainly feels like lying.
In the bad way will always exist some who uses this tech to do bad things, imagine a hacked robot controlled at distance at the wrong hands.

Selling the early fantasy of what something could be gives companies the funding for research and development. People pay a lot of money and get something non-functional, so it feels like a scam even if the intentions are good. The masses should never have access to an unfinished product. The best thing they could have done is train the robot for a very specific task, like doing laundry. At least if it could be immediately useful, they could proceed rolling out updates for other tasks. This would be the correct way to do this instead of having a robot that's terrible at everything. People want to see an immediate return on investment.

The main issue I see is right now, and probably in a decade, a lot of what this robot promises to be able to do, can be done better and cheaper with less than a dozen purpose-built automated devices. Answering the door? Smart lock and motorized hinge attachment. Vacuuming? Roombas have been a thing for over 20 years. Laundry? While not total automation, 2-in-1 washer/dryers exist. What something like this would be good for, item retrieval/transportation, cooking, cleaning counters and tables, while not nothing, are, as you said, clearly something the 'AI' won't be fully capable of for a while, and most intelligent people wouldn't trust it to do it right for a while longer.   Honestly, the most likely avenue I see for this tech, especially as the VR interface improves, is something like a telecommuting live-in housekeeper service sort of thing. Which isn't necessarily a bad route for it to go down. Zero risk of disease communication, no commute time or having to live somewhere else, having the robot only call for a pilot when something is requested would allow for more efficient use of human resources than having one person on call per house at all times, minimized risk of staff being physically abused, etc. It would almost certainly still be a luxury service, but a much more practical one.

Robotics researcher here yea there is 0 chance it actually does any of that stuff autonomously right now. Closest are maybe Pi and TRI, and even that's not truly generalizable zero shot at all in the way shown in the video and are wayyyyy simpler hardware than a humanoid. This sort of robotics is a hot research topic for a really good reason... because it isn't remotely ready or solved. Not only is getting that to work in a lab bleeding cutting edge, but getting it to work reliably in actual deployments??? Hell no not even close. Hail Marying trying to mass collect data by scamming people in an attempt to get your foundation model to work is not cool, and while it maybe helps push robotics to an extent it messes with people's trust in the industry and in robotics as a whole.

By the way, technology that allows distinguishing different shapes and objects already exists. Matrox's smart cameras are already able to do all of that, they are extremely good at pattern recognition, being used at factories to define a bad product on a conveyor belt or else. So it's only a question of giving it correct training data - possibility is already there.

I imagine there being a market for remote controlled chores robots. Would have to be cheaper than paying a maid in the long run for rich, non-old people, but for old people with good insurance it could be the difference between living at home while not being able to perform all tasks by yourself and having to move to a senior home, so people can take care of you cheaper than having to hire a nurse to be there every day. The people remote controlling the robots could be living on the other side of the world, making a few bucks on the side. Of course the company selling such subscriptions should be liable for any misconduct and therefore take care that none happens.

While I agree with your main concern about the large gap between Neo's current capability vs. his ideal/final stage, it does feel  some of your concerns are somewhat biased and/or influenced by fear of the unknown. In particular, you mentioned the need for Neo getting the right medicine(s) right for an elderly person. Common sense should rule here. That is, I personally would not fully delegate this task to Neo, or not even a helper/human for that matter (We all know humans definitely make mistakes too!). I might instead dispense said medicines in a ready to serve pill container. A simpler task I may be more comfortable w/ a robot (or human maid) doing. Teleoperation training: This is not an open ended event. That is, a teleoperated Neo does not get to roam endlessly around the house. And you do get to decide if & when you want such training for Neo, then schedule it, and eventually approve for such event to start. Once done, teleoperation is done. I could see maybe ~5 training sessions for complex tasks like doing a full laundry cycle. The AI should be smart enough to take it from there. Similarly for other tasks around the house. From what I've seen how fast AI learns, I think this is more realistic than expecting Neo to endlessly roam around not knowing how to do things. Weight/sturdiness: Neo's light weight is definitely intentional. While true that Neo has strength limitations, his abilities are actually on-par with what is needed for daily house chores. from a safety perspective, I personally wouldn't want a much heavier robot with Terminator like strength. The chances for real, more serious, accidents exponentially increases the heavier and stronger the robot gets. Cost: I agree, $20K sounds like a lot, but cost analysis vs. human labor quickly shows Neo's cost effectiveness. For instance, here in CA, even at a base wage of $25/hr. this translates to ~$4300/mo. ($51,600/yr.). So, Neo would quickly pay for itself in less than 6 months! But personally and practically speaking, I would opt for the monthly subscription which is basically a 6 mo. lease. I'm definitely willing/able to afford 6 months of Neo, and see how useful it would be for me and my elderly mother at home. For me, the upside way outweighs the initial learning curve Neo will need to go thru.

Sorry, but I just don't see humanoid robots happening.  It just doesn't make sense.  My Roborock cleans and vacuums my floors, not a humanoid robot pushing a vacuum cleaner or mop.  My Husqavarna 315x mows my lawn, not a humanoid robot filling gas into my mower, priming, starting and pushing the mower around my yard.  A self driving car is not "driven" by a humanoid robot sitting in the drivers seat.  Our clothes dryer is not a humanoid robot taking the clothes out of the washer, taking them outside and hanging them on a clothes line.  The example shows a humanoid robot opening the door, why?  Everyone has door bell cameras, so when you want the door opened just tell your smart device to open the front door.   Every where we go doors automatically open for us.  So maybe the hinges on your door need to be replaced by some kind of powered hinges to automatically open your door for you.  Our trash/recycle pick up was done by a truck driver and a couple of guys hanging off the back.  But now its just the driver, he pulls up to your cans, pushes a button and a huge arm spins around, grabs your cans and dumps into the truck.  How long before that is an AI based truck?  There are obviously thousands of scenarios and I cant cover them all.  Laundry?  Well maybe that's a smart hamper.  When it gets to a certain weight then it drives itself into a "machine" that pulls/sucks out all the clothes, washes, dries and folds them?  Dunno.  All of our machines and devices are being replaced by smarter ones.  So humanoid robots?   Just not needed.

Generational shifting products are simply NOT built by incrementation.   There was a Blackberry.. then there was an iPhone. No transition, just a solid shift. A new paradigm that obliterates the old one.   There are too many Agile coaches around tech now, where deep-thinking designers should be.   This is what I call a Investor-Customer 2-Narratives Project -- which is basically now how the Valley, VC groups or other tech hubs worldwide hype each other and invest like they were born to interbreed. :)   This class of project fundamentally sells to Investors* the idea that it is feasible to "just start somewhere, and then iterate" but, conversely, it sells to Consumers* that this very low functionality/feature bar IS the new paradigm, the new shift.   It is not. It is just a start. In fact, more like a "premature Swiss-knife prototype" turned into a commercial offer. Not truly good for anything. Not ready. Not solving any real issues. Just sufficiently story-told to grab the early adopter's brain.    If early adopters jump, investors and speculators put more money down, in the hopes the story earns another chapter now in the hands of the regular consumer. It doesn't REALLY need to be finished, ready or actually do anything meaningfully right or completely. It just needs to fly... because the consumer says so.   So far as we can see, the consumer does NOT really want robots. Founders do. Hence this cash-fest of small increment building nothing, for nobody, with no real immediate purpose or solution, but with a magnanimous dream-like offer.. for some day in the future.   @Mkbhd is right on the money when he says "why not unlock my door with a voice-based app?" for the consumer. However, if he said that to the other side (investors, speculators, bs product founders and other wave-riders), he would be a "hater of innovation" or someone without any real vision.    This building practice got us all used to the idea that an unfinished future-promising (but not delivering) prototype should be enough to make capital hungry speculators cash huge on "early adopters".  Harsh take I know.

Well, to the CEO's credit, he was transparent and didn't lie. From the beginning, he said that behind the robot, there could be a person for certain tasks, those that are more complicated for an AI, and that this would serve to train the AI so that at some point it can perform these tasks on its own. On the other hand, there is another approach that can be taken with this, and that is remote work. It will be possible to hire people who live in other places or even in other countries without those people needing to be in the countries where they do the work, provided there is a good internet signal, and specialized on both sides. This will be perfectly possible with top-quality Starlink antennas (ideally more powerful than those used in homes) on both sides (where the robot is located and where the operator is). This could lead to job creation in developing countries, eliminating the need for migration. This applies not only to domestic work but especially to factories, construction, livestock farming, and agriculture. The point is, AIs are still a ways off from achieving the same dexterity and precision as humans. Of course, they will already be able to perform some tasks, but they will be more rudimentary, such as vacuuming (they will struggle with a broom). AIs can move parts from one shelf to another, but inserting a bolt is much more difficult.

It's easy to criticize, to find fault, and to doubt. It's much harder to create. If someone like Marcques had had his way back in 2015, just imagine what he might have said about Tesla and their efforts at full self-driving technology. People like him think they're the ones who can cause companies to fail simply by pointing out flaws. But if we only listened to the doubters, we'd never see truly great innovations.  Now look at what Neo and his team at 1X are doing. They've come up with something ingenious: using a tele-operated home bot to get real-time input from homeowners. It allows those who are willing to engage to provide feedback that helps the technology evolve. Without that kind of forward-thinking approach, these innovations might stay stuck in factories and never make it into our homes.  In other words, what Neil's team is doing is genuinely amazing, and itâ€™s likely that many other companies will follow their lead.

The internet is a bizarre place.  Especially YouTube.  We finally have a product that can start to deliver the future that had been thought to be so, so, so much farther off in the future. Until 8 years only those following AI and working in the field had any idea what the future MIGHT hold (it was just starting to take shape in the greatest minds in AI on the planet).  But the world didn't notice a thing.  Then one fateful day, November 30th 2022, Open AI released, free, ChatGPT upon the world. Nothing would ever be the same again because the future was here and we had NO IDEA HOW IT WORKED!  It's like the social isolation from social media terrified everyone so badly it made everyone completely incapable of celebrating  ever again. And even a sudden concept like legit AI (I prefer AR; Artificial Reasoning) performing miracles every 3 months, then month, then 2-weeks, then week, then days, then day.......  Then suddenly one day it happened. AI was making advances so quickly that no one could keep up anymore. We had known by the concept of recursion that it would be fast, but we still weren't ready. Just 3 years after that day in 2022 we have gone from a model that can do a decent rhyme, to the models we see today. Global priorities have changed forever. The moto; Win at all costs. Politics has changed forever. The moto; again, Win at all costs.  And somehow we see all of this once in a life-time insanity and, against all odds and logic, people, who are too afraid to do anything but repeat what every other "EdgeLord69: Negative Comment Master Edition - Now with extra nasally sarcasm AND Lifetime Loneliness +12 and Dissatisfaction + 10 buffs,  are making jokes about the greatest technological period this planet will ever see.  Let me explain what made everyone so utterly out of touch with reality. Its fairly simple. But only if you were a computer and tech nerd in 1989. Which, by the way, was fucking no-one in this comment section right now, except for maybe 3 geriatric cunts. In 1993 no one alive bragged about having a PC except to their very, very best of friends. The reason: If you talked about PC's in high school in '93, you know what happened?..   Goodbye anus virginity at lunch break.  1 - None talked about computers. Ever.  But a change was coming. Computer games were getting amazingly fun. Popular kids suddenly had no option to admit - Consoles were pretty cool; Bye virtue of the Arcade Games that came before them.  Respect Achievement: UNLOCKED!  Then came the Bulletin Boards (nerd city). Then came the Early Internet in 98 or whenever. This is something that even me, a junior network administrator barely noticed. The public; they didnt understand it for years. With it came free music and video... at 1 pixel per minute. But that sped up and suddenly free music and eventually free movies became possible. Again the Nerds had done it. They had made the impossible - possible.  Cool Achievement: UNLOCKED!  But alas, Big Business was getting involved. Metallica sued for copyright. They wanted us to pay for shit again. The problem was, they couldn't enforce it. The wealthy trembled and plotted for ways to make money and tried* (Tried: [past tense] To attempt do a thing and fail like a little b*tch) to bring back wealth inequality.   Technology Is Cool Achievement: UNLOCKED!  Then came Microsoft. Google. PayPal. Adobe. Fruity loops etc, etc, and we pirated everything we could. And it was good.  But Google. Microsoft. Intel. IBM etc had started laying the ground work for something big... and were biding their time.  Then a new guy showed up out of nowhere. It was called The Facebook. We didn't know it then but things were about to change forever. The now 'Facebook' burst onto the scene, along with Instagram and eventually Twitter. Life was about to change forever. You see: It was becoming obvious  to business' around the world that you HAD to be online to stand a chance of surviving. And thats what the world did, it went online where 'the kids' were. And humanity paid a heavy price. Socialising - Gone. Friends - Gone. Casual sex - Gone. House parties - On life support. Pubs/Clubs - On life support. Doing 'random fun shit' with mates - gone. Hanging out at the servo on Friday night simply because you could - Gone... and Feminism - Blowing up but lacking any purpose, like a Gen-Z penis on Saturday night.  Finally, TikTok entered the chat. And all was "officially" lost.  But then the stirrings of a miracle. You see that brief window of "Cool + Respect" got some brilliant minds thinking about the next big thing. They had read about it in Sci-Fi books and magazines for their entire lives. It was of course the idiotic concept of Artificial Intelligence (the general concept that is, not what we incorrectly call AI today) had seemed like a total pipe dream for 40 years. It still seemed 100 years away in 2000. But now those brilliant minds were starting to say insane things like "Maybe it wasn't idiotic?". So they started thinking.  It was hard, slow and they had little to show for its efforts. But they carried on in the darkness unperturbed. Every now and then it made a small headline for an improved spelling option or a language translator. Nothing much. 'Watson' won Jeopardy. No one cared.. or even knew what was happening. Something called Alexnet in 2012 that no one but the most hardened machine learning enthusiasts knew about was born.  Then one day in 2016 Google's behemoth narrow AI called AlphaGo beat probably the best Go player, and 9-dan champion Lee Sedol. This had been considered impossible. Humans had spent probably millennia playing Go and most pro players dedicated their entire lives to mastering it. It was a huge moment that birthed 'move 37' which was studied ad nauseum. And so a gentle rumble started.  The very next year Google released an unassuming paper called "attention is all you need" and it opened the flood gates. Open AI, a start-up funded by Elon Musk took the paper and ran with it. Meanwhile DOTA 2 fell to The Open AI 5. Then Googles 'Alpha Star' beat a group of top Starcraft 2 players. As a lifetime fan of the game I shed a tear that day... even though it wasn't seen as a fair win. It demonstrated that an AI could outperform the best in the world at real-time decision making. What was worse; they had to restrict the AI's 'thoughts' (measured in APM - Actions Per Minute) to that of the best pro StartCraft 2 player.. and it still destroyed them with its un-Godly Blink Stalker 'micro' alone.  Beating humans at their games had gone from impossible to inevitable in a decade. AI won Texas Hold-em but nerds dont care about poker, so no one cared much. Finally ChatGPT was released in 2022 and the rest we know.  So my point is simple..  Oh wait, Alpha fold predicted the 3D shape of all 200 million known protein shapes with 95% accuracy. No big deal.  Anyway.. my point is simple.. I had to watch and wait for a decade as those things lost to AI. Now things like that happen every single day but on levels that are far, far more impressive. In fact they are so many and so impressive that we cant even keep up, let alone explain anything.  We live in a time when unthinkable miracles happen nearly every day. And it is only getting faster. Yet already it seems like the unquenchable pessimism and glazed with boredom eyes, of the internet can barely bring itself to give a sarcastic slow-clap to. THE MOST INSANE SHIT THAT HAS EVER HAPPENED. And will continue to do EVERYDAY, possibly FOREVER.  If an AI robot with God-like knowledge, is running around your house doing whatever you tell it to do, and you still arent impressed. "Zen zher ish no pleeshing you". Ever I suspect.

I think this robot is great. The best part is not the robot itself. It's the business model.  First, the robot is helping people, but not autonomously, the robot is controlled remotely to help people, at the same time, it is also training itself by remote control. Second, the business model is not only to train the robot, but also to earn the money by renting or by selling the robot.  The current situation now is that most robotic companies they train their robotic on their own. The process is slow and expensive. So by renting it to the clients and controlling it remotely to gain the money and training is a win-win situation.

If we make an intelligence capable enough the get all these tasks right, how close would that intelligence be to 'near human'? I've been thinking for a while that we really need to get our definitions down for AIs that deserve ethical consideration versus those that do not because they are essentially a more advanced screwdriver. It's ok to enslave a screwdriver, but not a 'near human' whatever that means. We can agree here is a line *somewhere*. And when we get into the territory of making one device/intelligence that is responsible for a wide variety of very different complex tasks, and especially of learning, understanding and integrating with a social unit (the family), I think we are approaching the danger zone for accidentally creating something that it would be unethical to enslave. Even if version 1.0 is nothing to worry about, the quest for performance will drive us closer and closer to the line as we make these household servants more capable. Compare this to a Roomba, which is more like the very advanced screwdriver. It has one job that it's specialised for and so its 'AI', if it needs any, can be relatively simple. That is the direction we should be driving our household technology.

I suspect that these robots will have local AI, so that they are learning about your house and training just that one instance of the AI program to know about your house.  Sure, the company's teleoperator will be able to memorize your house while he or she is training the robot's AI, but the extent of what that local AI will need to learn is YOUR house.  And each robot will have different training data which is unique to the individual house that it's in, and none of the other robots will have that data because they are in different houses. The AI in Tesla cars have to be trained on the roads for everybody--but you have to remember that the roads that we all travel, and the traffic situations that we all confront, are the same for everybody.  Each state has unique laws, but all the roads are public to all the cars.  That one robot that you buy will be trained on YOUR house because that's all it needs to know about. I don't think that this answers your concerns, I actually agree with you.  But it's a detail in the argument that is worth clarifying.

Honestly the biggest thing holding bad humanoid robotics right now may be the lack of sensory perception. It's not enough to stick some cameras and microphones on a mannequin head and then use state estimation to figure out where each rigid body part is. It needs to be able to feel if something is touching it. It needs to be able to distinguish between the tactile properties of something sticky versus something smooth. It needs to be constantly aware of itself as a whole. Without that, you just can't get the refined adaptive behavior that you need to make sure it can handle things carefully or avoid knocking things over or avoid falling over. That means it has to be weak and slow just to do a fraction of the things you would want, and even that is assuming it has fine motor abilities (which this thing clearly does not).  They're trying to sell an idea as a product with no path to making it real. The question is whether they drank their own kool-aid or whether they're deliberately trying to deceive customers.

Even the Boston Dynamics videos are somewhat cherry-picked as they (usually) donâ€™t include the many times the robot fails to carry out itâ€™s routine, and sometimes give a false impression of full-autonomy when in reality a lot of the movements are highly choreographed for a specific scenario, a bit like a Disneyland animatronic. That doesnâ€™t make them any less impressive but you can imagine how someone might walk away from these videos thinking that the company has developed a set of fully autonomous humanoid robots when the reality is that these are very much just R&D projects.  The only commercialized robot theyâ€™ve created after years of R&D is the Spot robot, and that is obviously a much more limited version of this concept. It doesnâ€™t try to do bipedal movement or complex locomotion but the end result is a robot that can actually be bought and isnâ€™t just a lab project.

There is a major difference between the Tesla training story and the humanoid robot training story. For a car, there is no way the manufacturer itself can organize training by itself. Even if they are willing to risk putting cars on the road without drivers and willing to pay for the damage when things go wrong, other cars / people on the road wonâ€™t agree to that. But home assistance can be trained in non-public environments that do not require public consensus where no risks can take place for any human. They need to arrange various indoor testing environments like with various washing machines, rooms structures and stuff, but all can be done behind closed doors. Even interactions with humans can be trained with employees instead of the customers. So it seems to me they donâ€™t face the same chicken-egg fallacy but just eager to make money quick.

You'll definitely be right, I'm with you. And I'm glad the mainstream seems to be catching up to the practices of these people. This is the holy grail, it is a goal worth pursuing, but we're not even remotely close to there yet. And yes, having lots of data would be helpful, but you can obtain that data in ways that are less misleading, honestly. Especially when you have basically infinite investment money...  It's not just the data, though, the data is one big hurdle, but even when overcoming that, there are still challenges. As you said, too many variables.

The economics of the â€œmarketâ€ just donâ€™t make sense to me.. let alone all of the rest of the functional and security issues.  Have these folk never had a robot vacuum and noticed just how fundamentally terrible a job it does!? 45 mins to do a 5-10 min task, less thoroughly. Theyâ€™re just scaling up the ineptitude.  Come advertise your robot when it can put away dishes in an over-crowded, semi-but-not-really-organised cupboard or drawer.. when it can dust or wipe down a bench under and around the fine corners of objects.. when it can vacuum under the dining chairs, couch, bed, bed sides (you know, where dust collects).. and when itâ€™s actually solving the bigger hurdle of laundry: sorting (folding is the low hanging fruit).. then maybe the economics might start making sense.. and then weâ€™ll just need to talk about privacy and security.  By the time the tech has reached that point, the once-thought-dystopian levels of class stratification will have eventuated so thoroughly that chattel slavery will render the unit economics of Rosie the Robot infeasible.

The problem I have with Tesla beta testers is that all of us, whether we like it or not, are beta testing with the musk fifis. Then also there was a time when beta testing was called what it is: a service to be compensated by the company. A machine that is almost okay at turning on the machine that always gets the dishes washed correctly and quickly is stupid. If you are the agent, your dishwasher was your immediate-most subagent, but now you've needlessly added an intermediate subagent. Also these models are data-hungry where your brain isn't. We meet unfamiliar things all the time, yet our ability to negotiate unfamiliarity doesn't require hundreds of training hours usually. Not enough of these are going to be sold and the billionaires who buy them are going to have to hire a maid or housekeeper to do most tasks anyway. This kind of product just externalizes a whole lot of environmental harm and results in new e-waste... And the opportunity cost logic doesn't really work: if you're inefficiently using a resource, it isn't because of the small things, it's because of the big ones. That kind of optimization is usually one you'd see like a stupid undergrad in an intro comp sci class doing, and is sometimes called premature optimization. The billionaire who buys this will have lost $20000 trying to skirt past the 3 minutes it takes to walk across their oversized houses to the front door.

Robot vacuums work pretty well for not being human shaped. And because it doesn't need an extended arm with someone/something attached to that arm means it can get under things without the obstruction s caused by the 'human shaped' way of doing it. And why would a robot need to use a smartphone? Wouldn't it be able to interact through Bluetooth or some kind of similar adaptive device. It is a computer, it can interface with computers without touching it?   I think we keep trying to find a one fits all solution when specific chore devices (like  the Roomba) end up b ing just a new way to do an old chore once you disconnect the idea of the old way it was shaped. I also think 2 legs vs wheels or a more balanced "lower" is what makes most of these humanoid robots so prone to falling over.

Â @DawnofNerdlifeÂ  But that's a complete different kind of idea. Your idea is to have 20 different robots in your home that can just do one task. The idea of this robot is to have just one sinlge robot that can do all the task in the already existing human home. And for this kind of robot the question is: human shape or not human shaped? For this kind of robot I think having a shape that is instantly compatibe with ALL the tools is the most usefull approach. Edit: About the smartphone thing:  why? because it just works, no matter what. Imagine you want him to do something inside an app for you. when he can use a smartphone it works. is the app using bluetooth? maybe not? Has it an API or something to which the robot can connect directly? Is that API even compatle with the version of robot you have? Who knows. But using the touchscreen of the smartphone will work ;)

Â @Dwarfo123Â  I'm not talking about the techinal implementation, but about the compatibility which comes with the human form in a world where everything is designed to be working with a human form ;)  Doesn't mean it has to mimic the looks of a real human. But the general shape makes it able to interact with everything that's already existing

Â @HolidayAtHomeÂ You really think by the time this technology works, an advanced robot will have bluetooth barriers.   And yes, I do think dedicated objects work better around the home in many cases. Like the roomba is decent as what it does because it doesnâ€™t need to be designed to do anything else. My pets auto feeder is good at what it does, because thatâ€™s all it does. Deliver Food to animal at a times interval I set.   And whatâ€™s mostly been happening with a lot of smart devices is they are extensions of a single controller (often your phone). But the design of the actual device that does the work (the roomba and auto feeder for example) doesnâ€™t need to do extra things, making it better designed for the task its doing instead of over complicating it with stuff you donâ€™t need it to do.   Also, under what world would I need a robot to use my phone? There are already accessibility devices, so it doesnâ€™t even help those folks out. I see smart devices filling the gap already upon which a robot is either an unneeded redundancy or filler for lazyness.

Â @DawnofNerdlifeÂ  ok then you are the guy with a backpack filled with an mp3 player, a camera, a phone, a internet communicator, a GPS device, a card reader, a video game console and a flashlight and I'm the guy that just has a smartphone in his pocket ;)  Of course your devices are better doing their own jobs,  but what are people carrying around in the end? The one single thing that does everything good enough . Of couse,  some have a dedicated camera or video game console, but noone wants to buy the full backpack anymore or skip having a smartphone because they have a dedicated camera. MP3 player and internet communicator even vanished because the smartphone just did it good enough because their own task was too easy to perform with a general purpose device. I guess feeding your pets will also be a task too easy to perform by a general purpose robot.  Imagine people starting their own household in 10-20 years when that robot tech is really matured. Will they really buy 20 different robots that just can do one task that takes just minutes or even seconds and do nothing all day long? Or one robot that can do it all and potentially do additional thing in the future with just a software update because the physical robot is build for general purpose?  I guess you won't convince them with your 20 robot approach just because your feeding robot is so unbelievable hyper great at feeding your pets...putting food from one container into another while doing absolutely nothing for 23 hours and 59 minutes a day.   Dude, I took way too much time for writing my comment, but it was fun ;) Let's see what will happen in the next years!

Â @HolidayAtHomeÂ As a person who camps, yes in certain situations it has been useful to have an actual flashlight over a phone, because a camping torch is better than a phone flashlight in pitch dark camping grounds. Most cameras are in phones, but legit photographers and cinematographers still prefer and use dedicated pro cameras.   Also on rural roads while camping I did keep a gps in the glove bocks because when the phone couldnâ€™t connect, it often got me safely to a main highway where then the smartphone would take over. The robot isnâ€™t replacing the vacuum (unless it suddenly gets attachments) it still needs to use it. Its not becoming the dishwasher, its loading it, its not being the water dispenser, its using it. And right now some of these devices are already growing more smart independently and being switched out to smart devices as there predecessors die out. With smart home controls tbat donâ€™t require a metal being navigating your home. And the smartphone already exist as a controller for  multiple smart devices that are having their own natural tech improvements of which a robot would be an add, not a  replace anyway. I think there will be a place for robots, but I donâ€™t know that place is â€˜consumer home servantsâ€™ (Especially not this wobbly thing).   But yes, the future will define itself and its often show to not be what we think.

Yeah, I wouldn't trust a company that claims that "it just needs more data" but can't show even the simplest autonomous demonstrations. I mean, sure, OK, you need more data. Couldn't you make 1 room for a demo and train the robot to recognize all objects in THAT room? Because you don't need a ton of data to recognize 1 type of cup or 1 green sweater that's always the same. The fact that they don't have even that minimal example tells me that they don't HAVE an actual autonomous algorithm finished even. If they have it at all. This will be another expensive gadget that cashes in on 1000 fools worldwide who have 20K for a cool toy - and then goes out of business most likely.  The business strategy here is probably to hire some workers in India for extremely low wages and have them clean your house in America. And not even bother developing the actual AI or collecting data.  Also, what about the maintenance? One of the MAJOR factors in making a commercial consumer-grade bipedal robot is that those joint motors wear out REALLY fast. We're talking weeks and months. I don't expect this robot to have solved that - otherwise it'd be front and center in their marketing. So the danger here is yes, it will work (as much as you can call the current state working) for a few months, and then it will need $800 knee replacement. And then a month later $1000 hip replacement. And it will basically keep wearing out on a loop every few months, most likely.

It is clear that people have stopped reading, because if they were,  this product would have never made it to market. Asimov's I robot would deter rational folks from ever even considering being in the same house with one of these monstrosities. With AI beginning to "hallucinate",  and now these becoming a reality, it is now just a matter of time before some dystopian robot take-over is inevitable.  The best we can hope for is a WALL-E type ending to this nightmare, the worst is Skynet rearing its ugly head, much to the chagrin of its makers and the rest of humanity. We are simultaneously brilliant, and moronic, in how we have shaped our future.

If it ever gets to the point where it can mow my lawn without getting the mower stuck in the ditch and pull weeds without pulling out the flowers, I'd consider buying one. But after watching it struggle to close the dishwasher, and how slowly - and poorly - it does simple things like put dishes away, I'll pass. (And yeah, I know it was being controlled by a human, but that just confirms that this thing is nowhere close to being ready for release. Let me know when it can fold a fitted sheet . . .

As someone who actually worked on products to help the disabled/ elderly what I noticed is how specialized those tools are and how they assist people in becoming independent.   If someone struggled with laundry we wonder why they are struggling with it. Is it the bending down? Lifting the basket? The arthritis? Missing fingers that can't open the door? Unable to walk? Mental illness?   There are different tools for all of these it's not one size fits all like this. Some tools need strength to support a human being and others need to be light and portable. Just cause a robot is human shaped it doesn't mean it's helpful.

If there were going to be one tool that could help many different people with many different tasks, then very likely this tool would have to be human-shaped. The tasks that a person used to be able to do by themself can, pretty much by definition, be done by a skilled-enough being that is human shaped. It's very unlikely that a non-human-shaped tool is going to be able to be as broadly helpful as a hypothetical effective human-shaped robot.  But precisely because a human-shaped robot would have to be able to do so many different things, so safely, on the basis of the kinds of tactile information that we've never gathered into recordings for training data, it's very unlikely that anything like this will be available soon.  It's a bold move for this company to try to get an army of tele-operated robots in people's homes, so that human operators can practice doing these tasks with a robot body, to generate the training data that some hypothetical future robots might be able to learn from to do these tasks on their own.  But for now, it's surely better for most people who want help to get a specialized tool for one or two things, unless they have sufficient resources to support another human being on a living wage.

6:15 The reveal stratagy has changed because the customer has changed. It used to be apple selling an iPhone to consumers, the product needed sales to succeed so they needed to actually be able to sell the thing. These days the customers are investors, and the theoretical consumers are just the actors to convince investors to buy into the company. The company DOES have their product available to sell when they make these releases, it's just that the product is company stock and investor reports, not a consumer appliance.

You make some interesting points. However, a great deal of general knowledge about the household is available in text, picture, and video format, and that could be used in mega training projects to bypass a lot of the preliminaries. For example, selecting and folding laundry: much of this could come out of general knowledge about clothes, folding things, furniture, and so on. For example: as a lad of 14, I was sent off to a military school where there was a very specific way to fold clothes, make beds, etc. Most of the training was done before it started: I knew what a bed was, what sheets were, what it means to fold things, what a shelf was. Also, the process was explained to me procedurally by my more experienced peers, and finally, by correcting my first attempts. If general knowledge is present, specific tasks are much easier to learn. The problem with pre-LLM robots is that general knowledge wasn't available to them. With LLMs, perhaps it will be.

AI in general is one big empty promise.  LLLM's are the only thing that are close to producing something at scale of value.  These are fancy regression model which is not learning, it's clumsy copying.  Learning would involve critically deconstructing and problem and generating a useful solution.  That isn't what "AI" does today.  It looks for enough similar problems that have already been solved and tries to apply the same solution.

People misunderstand what AI is for. It is for big business enhancing productivity. For shaping public opinion on social websites. For stock manipulation. For data analysis, customer targeting, marketing.  Robotic AI is such a niche, and such low income by comparison, it's practically a hobby project. Unless the military gets involved, but that's another story...  What's worse, any real robotic butlers coming out, and we're looking at 30 to 50 years in the future - will be permanently network connected and will be used - same as Windows 11 - to gather information on it users, for its the big business masters.

This is brilliant technology at the bleeding edge. This is only version 1, so they have to sell the dream: what V1 can become, not what V1 is today.  NEO has kept the human in the loop, which is the key to success with early stage AI products.  With V1â€™s capabilities, they can outsource the tele-operation to locations with labour supply and achieve massive scale.  Using that same principle, NEO can use teleoperation to train the robot on each unique house it operates in, learning where the fridge, dishwasher, washing machine and cupboards are. Keep doing that until the software learns to do it with little to no human control â€” just like Tesla self driving, Waymo, SpaceX Starship, etc.  This is a great vision of the future which is not too distant.  My view is that the gap between the promise and the product is not that big, and I fully support this visionary product.

Asmongold had a couple of great points:   1. Was during the Neo demo video, an older guy asks it if he's holding paprika. The robot correctly identified the spice bottle as Cayenne pepper. Then the guy asks "where are my glasses?", Neo tells him they're hanging off his shirt collar/pocket. Then guy asks him "can i use this in my chilli", Neo tells him sure, just be careful how much as it can make it really spicy. Now...how long before some dummy puts his glasses in some chilli cause Neo told him to, then turns around and sues the company into oblivion for trying to poison/kill him? 2. You're gonna end up with a bunch of clueless "operators" in India somewhere, that'll be controlling these robots in your house. They'll have access to their remote camers, mics, and be able to physically touch and move objects around. How long before the f-ckery starts? Stolen personal info, various pranks, retaliation against annoying customers, or other malicious behavior? 3. What if I want to train the robot to pleasure me? That means an operator most likely has to take over and manually perform that activity? If I'm a guy...and the operator is a dude...does that make me gay? Or is it like schrodingers box...as long as I don't know who the operator is it, all possibilities remain open? 4. You own the robots here in the US. Labor laws don't apply to them. What if a farmer buys 20 of these do do farm/field work. What if the tele-operators are located in a country with no anti-slavery laws, and are working for free (besides food/housing). That would technically not be illegal in the US persumably? Just curious...

I have told many people that autonomy and LLMs are not at the point it needs to be.  A good first step is Hierarchical Reasoning Models (HRMs) but they claim way too much.  The problem is autonomy works best in a fairly simply defined situations.  Paradoxically, flying is one of these areas, it can be done.  The problem with self-driving is there will likely always be situations that are unique.  A human can figure it out.  Not current AI.  It is getting better but I think it will take at least 5 years, maybe 10, and yes, I have done Machine Learning myself.

I have gone through a few different robo vacuum cleaners.  The first one randomly navigated a room - no intelligence except to turn when it bumped into an object, and I suppose it also knew how to find the dock.  Next one was better.  It mapped rooms and was more methodical in how it vacuumed.  Third one added in lidar, and was better at avoiding cables and "biological deposits" (aka dog poop) - but not perfect!  This was probably in a span of 8 years or so?  I still spend time each week assisting the robots - they get stuck, remove clogs, fill water tank, etc.  I think vacuuming is a much simpler task and see plenty of room for improvement.  Now, the Neo robot looks cool in the video - but when you find out it does not really do anything without a human behind it, I think a useful robot is years in the future (maybe 10-20??)

PhD in robotics here: The problem of autonomously picking an arbitrary object by a robot has not been fully solved. While robots can achieve high success rates in controlled environments with specific objects, handling the infinite variability of objects and environments encountered in the real world remains a major challenge and an active area of research. In this type of problems, more training data can help, but does not guarantee success (for the time being).
It makes sense to launch the robot incomplete, because it needs training data from customers homes in order to be able to become autonomous.

And I started thinkingâ€¦ what if a circuit blows or something goes wrong while itâ€™s holding that knife? There was even a video showing a similar bug once.  I honestly donâ€™t believe those robots will run on local LLMs with expensive GPU's â€” theyâ€™ll definitely be connected to the cloud, meaning two cameras recording 24/7. I donâ€™t know about you, but I couldnâ€™t sleep in the same house with something like that watching me all the time. And honestly, this robot looks so damn creepy.

Personally, Iâ€™m totally in favor of robots without AI, the ones controlled only by humans. That way, we could keep a lot of jobs and avoid a total collapse of the service industry. Imagine being able to buy a kind of VR setup to control a robot from home, you could work remotely as a cleaner, cook, repair tech or even doctor. Everyone would just have their own docking station at home, like a robot vacuum, and whenever someone needs a service, they just order it and a real person connects to this robot to get the job done. Sure, itâ€™s a pretty idealistic vision, but honestly, even in the worst-case scenario, Iâ€™d still prefer that over the whole AI takeover thing.

6:13   This approach represents the most effective path toward developing fully autonomous AI companions. Artificial intelligence learns through repetition and exposure, not theory. By designing a human-guided training program where AI consistently learns from real interactions, it can eventually perform complex actions independentlyâ€”and in a convincingly human-like way.  Waiting for other AI systems to â€œcatch upâ€ through passive trainingâ€”like video datasets or controlled simulationsâ€”will only create brittle intelligence. Those environments lack the unpredictable variables of real life: kids interfering, pets reacting, or older family members interacting differently. Itâ€™s precisely these unpredictable factors that make real-world learning invaluable.  Training in genuine household settings offers a long-term advantage. It cultivates adaptability, empathy, and nuance that controlled environments canâ€™t replicate. In essence, this is how you raise an AI capable of understanding life as it is lived, not just as it is modeled.  AI development mirrors human developmentâ€”especially in its early stages. Like a toddler, it learns best through immersion, trial, and error until it eventually surpasses its teachers in that domain. These are the baby steps toward an AI capable of fulfilling the promises often exaggerated by marketing. Current AI isnâ€™t anywhere near the sci-fi portrayals we imagineâ€”or even something as practical as autonomous dishwashingâ€”but this method lays the foundation for getting there.

Sorry, but I am here to warn you about your professional pessimism. This new technology is extremely exciting. It clearly also is not meant for mass consumers, hence the extremely steep price. Sure, your point about not buying based on future claims is true. But it also is great that companies make the technology of tomorrow available today. Especially in this case, I think it is clearly all about enthusiasts and not the masses. Your video frames it as bad. You are at danger of a phenomenon widely spread over most professions, that the deeper you are into the matter, the more pessimistic you are about the developments in this field. You begin to see only the downsides of the technology in your field and arenâ€™t excited about new developments. This is in part due to your bubble, where you are always kept up to date, through the reporting of even small development steps, so when the product is announced, it disappoints you because of a perceived lack of innovation. See it this way: You could have focused your video more on how exciting it is to be able to buy a remote-controlled humanoid robot into your home to even help them get better. But you only focused on the part where it doesnâ€™t match the expectations of being the perfect surprise innovation of a fully autonomous home assistant. I hope you will reflect on this, so future videos are again more about how exciting technology can be (while also highlighting the rough edges), instead of basically a consumer warning video with the information attached.

This has always been a common practice in business. Being the first to develop a product, often called the "first-mover advantage" is crucial. Even if the product isnâ€™t fully ready, what truly matters is getting it out first. Doing so allows this company to shape the market, set customer expectations, and build strong brand recognition before competitors inevitably follow (and in this market, they'll definitely follow). Early movers can establish customer loyalty, secure key partnerships and distribution channels, and accumulate valuable data or patents that create long-term barriers to entry. By setting the standard for innovation in their space, they not only capture early attention and market share but also make it harder for others to compete without appearing as imitators.

I think you were being very kind. There are so many potential pitfalls - I would say the problem space is much more complex than self driving as roads for the most part have clear markings and consistent rules whereas the insides of a house do not. Not only that, even when someone teleoperates the robot they clearly struggle (presumably because depth perception and FOV in a VR headset is limiting) - so I'm not convinced they will even do a good job that way. Imagine if you not only have to contact the company to organise a teleoperation appointment, you then have to have a 'stranger' you can't see essentially in your home and they still may well have problems doing the job that you may have to interfere to explain or help with. Realistically, it's just not going to work. I'm not convinced affordable, personalised home robots will be solved to a satisfactory level in the next decade (going off self driving track record) but we will see.

995 of what Boston Dynamics developed is outdated. They are a pre-AI company. Their robots are moved by sophisticated algorithms, that took 20 years to perfect. Today an intern can download a simulation package and train an AI to move the robot better in a day or two. The hard part is building a humanoid body, especially the hands, that's dexterous enough, strong enough, reliable enough, durable enough, but also fits into the human form factor, affordable, and can be mass produced. Then you still need a brain, A cutting-edge real-world AI that understands the world enough to do basic tasks at least.

I don't know where people are getting this about Boston Dynamics.  They have one of the most advanced robots right now with the latest Atlas.  Its problems are is it is expensive as all get out, no where near ready for mass production, and not any more capable of fine movent than most of the others.  For broader movement is one of, if not, the best and has really good spacial awareness.  Like all of the others though it isn't ready to learn everything about someone's home or any of the other things a person would want a home robot to do.  That isn't to say no others compete.  Optimus could really go far since there is so much research overlap between it, self-driving cars, Grok, etc.  At the moment Optimus feels more like it would be for home use and Atlas would be more for industrial(construction/warehouse/etc) use.  Neither is truly ready to go though.  Whether Neo will actually see mass use first or just be first to market we will have to see. I appreciate marques' reaction here, and I agree with him on basically every other genuine AI product that was sold before it completely worked. But for things like this: I truly believe that the main business model for humanoid robots for a very, very long time is (and always was expected to be!) labor arbitrage from poor countries into rich countries without having to deal with the consequences of people physically crossing borders all the time. I honestly interpret them to just be selling exactly what most people are ultimately going to be buying in this space for a long time (a part-time maid that physically resides somewhere far away with lower wages and no commute time) and that the AI thing is so irrelevant that it's not even that awful that they are kind of being deceptive about it since it hardly matters.

Stupid believers don't seem to understand why we as humans take years to develop hand eye coordination, gross motor, executive decisions making... because we need to do all these things perfectly in the exact environments in which we practice them. A robot that is run of the mill out of the box isn't going to understand the different approaches to item ergonomics, nuances of affordance, and appropriate usage. You're telling me that you honestly think that one robot is going to understand how every dishwasher looks like, the grasps of the handle, and all the appropriate locations of every model of dishwasher out there? At best, you could get the macro scale things done, like opening a door or turning on a light switch or picking up a box or something. Things that are insanely common sense and don't require rote in-environment learning, scripting, guidance , etc.

You're letting them off the hook WAY too easily.   Yes, these companies DO need beta-testers to provide them with valuable and absolutely necessary training data.  Not because that's the only way to get that data -- but because it's the only PROFITABLE WAY TO GET THAT DATA.   They COULD produce that data themselves, but they'd have to PAY to have it done.  Which they don't want to do, because it would cut into their PROFITS.   So they foist an UNFINISHED PRODUCT on the public, and have THEM become the beta testers.

I think youre right on point. It makes far more sense to have multiple specialized devices, one that opens your door, another that washes and folds clothes, another that does the dishes or cooks meals, each built to handle specific environments and expectations. Current general purpose AI systems, especially cloud based ones, can already manage these kinds of repeatable, structured tasks. This is still an open market because these kinds of practical, everyday robots donâ€™t yet exist. Eventually, true general purpose robots that can do everything will arrive. The big companies are pushing toward that, and they certainly have the resources. The question is whether it will take one year or a hundred. The things you mentioned are often underestimated. Most people donâ€™t realize how hard it is to make a robot on legs navigate a changing environment and remember what it learns. Ive looked closely into the technologies involved while researching for my own business over the past six months, and I really dislike how often companies promote what they want their product to be rather than showing tangible, truthful, time based progress.
