I think they're missing a major use case for these in their rush for 'autonomous'. If it mechanically works as shown, screw cleaning the house. Give the VR gear to the buyer. Think of the handicapped/immunocompromised people that for various reason's can't leave their homes. Something like this would be able to let them actually go to events, go out with friends, etc.   Industrial versions would be even better. Miners, certain types of factory workers, fire fighters, search and rescue in dangerous areas, bomb disposal, etc could all be done with a robot like this while the human are safely off to the sides. Hell, on the mining front the time savings would be worth buying them alone. Instead of the transit time for the miners to get from the surface to the mining site, one miner finishing their shift can just hand the headset off to the next miner. That alone would save hours of time.   They're all chasing the 'fully autonomous' market but are missing a massive market that would likely jump at the chance to use them.

I think that this may in some ways be an easier problem to solve than self driving cars. Robot vacuums are pretty commonplace nowadays and do okay navigating around the house. AI is also well suited for object recognition and navigation. I also think the robot deliberately doesn't have that much strength so it can't cause as much damage when something does go wrong.  I also understand the concept of inviting an expert in your house to complete a task, but my expectation would be that they would do the task a couple of times and after that the robot would've learnt how to do things on its own. That would have to be the idea, because the solution just isn't scalable otherwise. I get that that's not ideal, but it's a good way to solve the problem of helping it find its way around a home and the specifics of each home.  It would be ideal if there was an option to train it yourself. Seeing as the company just uses regular Meta Quest hardware, I don't see how that would be a problem.  The much bigger challenge I think is utility. Is there really that much to do around the house? This is competing against a cleaner. A good cleaner is say $80 an hour. This is $500 per month. So it's this or a good cleaner for 1.5 hours a week. Or if you buy it outright, it's 1.5 hours per week for 3 years to break even. It feels like it makes more sense as a commercial solution. Cleaning large offices for example isn't difficult, just very time consuming and there are specific problems with that industry that this would be uniquely positioned to fix.

True story:  Three nights ago my wife awoke at 3am.  She could hear soft, stealthy noises, and after a short time, flickering light.  She quietly woke me to investigate. By the time I got out of bed, our robot vacuum cleaner bumbled through the door, turned hard left, and disappeared under the dresser... it was very reluctant to come out! I soon discovered that we had an electricity outage.  For some reason it had triggered a 'Cleaning Cycle' for the vac.  It had done a lovely job of the living room, where it lives under the TV cabinet.  Eventually the battery got low, and as it could not detect the powered-down base, it went into its alternative 'Home-search mode' of following walls until it finds base, or goes flat! Your robot doesn't need to beat you to death... it can just sneak up and give you a heart attack!

Totally get the criticism, most of what we saw is teleop, not full autonomy. But that doesnâ€™t make it fake; it makes it a bridge. Teleoperation lets you ship something useful now, earn money, and collect the real-world demos that actually teach the robot to be autonomous later.  Weâ€™ve already seen this work: stores have run shelf-stocking robots with people driving in VR, delivery bots use human takeover on the weird edge cases, and there are cafÃ©s in Japan where home-based/disabled workers teleoperate service robots and get paid. So yes, â€œoperate a robot, get paidâ€ isnâ€™t sci-fi.  My angle: whatâ€™s wrong with remote control if it creates jobs today? People in lower-income regions could freelance as robot operators for homes and businesses in richer markets. In elder care, a remote caregiver could â€œbe thereâ€ through a robot when staffing is tight. Just be transparent about whatâ€™s autonomous vs. teleop, lock down privacy, and measure progress by how fast the autonomy improves. Teleop isnâ€™t the conâ€”itâ€™s the on-ramp.

Youâ€™re rightâ€”the demo sells a big dream while most of it is teleop (Joanna Stern showed that, and the keynote labels only two autonomous moments). But thereâ€™s a real upside: teleoperation isnâ€™t a scam, itâ€™s a bridge. Human-in-the-loop lets teams ship useful capability now, earn revenue, and collect the demonstrations that train the model toward autonomy, exactly how complex systems mature.  My take: whatâ€™s actually wrong with remote control? It can open a new labor market, people in developing countries could freelance as robot operators for homes and businesses in wealthier markets and get paid. In elder care, a remote caregiver could â€œbe thereâ€ through a robot instead of importing labor. Itâ€™s a smart interim stage: be transparent about whatâ€™s autonomous vs. teleop, enforce strict privacy/geo-fencing, and use Expert Mode to build the data flywheel. Youâ€™re right about the gapâ€”but teleop is the bridge that can get us across it faster.

The thing is, this isnâ€™t an independent humanoid robotâ€”itâ€™s essentially a remote-controlled human assistant. A low-cost-per-hour maid for wealthy individuals, operated from across the globe through a robotic interface. Itâ€™s dystopian, itâ€™s disturbing, but itâ€™s undeniably capitalistic: imagine having a domestic worker you donâ€™t have to pay like a â€œrealâ€ human, because their labor is outsourced to countries with lower wages. This is the trajectory of extreme capitalism, and it genuinely saddens me. Just like Facebook exploiting low-income regions for their "censorship detection", or ChatGPT relying on undervalued labor for data training, this model will inevitably expand. They only say AI because it is trendy right now, but it's little to do with the realistic expectations that anyone should put on these products, instead we should criticize them for the path they're moving towards. It's not about AI, at all, it's about launching a product and using AI to accelerate exposure and make investors interested.

Great take on this. I often struggle, with the reality of where we are vs the promise. AI products are definitely full tilt improving, but I just donâ€™t see the predicted jumps being made by the industry. Having even a moderate understanding of how the various models work in ML/AI an hour playing with products pretty quickly shows how non-iterative they are. It becomes quite apparent that the scale or power, efficiency, or full stop technological breakthrough required to get beyond the plateau weâ€™ve arrived at is pretty monumental. Yes Vision models have improved in accuracy for classification and short videos can be quite impressive, even the uncanny responses in LLMs are very impressive as long as long as the post model memory doesnâ€™t get too deepâ€¦ The context depth just doesnâ€™t scale for complexities we take for granted. I have hope, but I think 2030 is a pipe-dream for complexities problems and there has to be some tangible ROI that makes these products really useful before the industry snd its investments may begin to implode before we get there. Iâ€™m hopeful but this brings me to my point.  Knowing a lot of people over the years in startups, I wouldnâ€™t doubt that preordering for these AI driven products is more than beta testing. It provides some level of reassurance to investors. Could even be a way to de-risk or in extreme cases recover a bad investment. This specific instance we are effectively investing on an emotional level by being an early adopter and at the price point you would be very invested for even the wealthier middle class worldwide. Look how much investment capital was pumped into Tesla and for how long. Will that investment ever be recovered? And people there is a preexisting use-case that makes buying a tesla an easy adoption for an expensive product. Those users provide the refinement of the models the car uses to In this case in order to have enough users. How does the producers of neo attract enough people to purchase this product to refine the training data so that some point it will be autonomous. Let along a humanoid is probably the most complicated style of robot to do this with. I just donâ€™t see it. To your point, Iâ€™d love to be wrong, but I donâ€™t have 20k Iâ€™d be wiling to throw away at the possibility of it flopping.

This isn't a product launch. It's a show for venture capitalists that you pay $20,000 for.  This is a crucial piece of reporting. The Wall Street Journal has meticulously documented what this $20,000 "consumer" robot actually is.  The summary: it's a non-autonomous, remotely operated device that performs tasks with agonizing slowness (five minutes to load three items into a dishwasher). Critically, its utility is directly dependent on the buyer signing a "social contract"â€”essentially agreeing to turn their home into a test lab and sacrifice their privacy for data collection.  This report brilliantly shows the "What." But it doesn't state the "Why."  And the "Why" is that this entire endeavor does not appear to be a consumer product strategy. It is an investment strategy, and the difference is fundamental.  No viable business model can be built on selling an inefficient, $20,000 surveillance device to a handful of enthusiasts. The "robotics slop" concept mentioned in the video isn't a new paradigm; it's just an attempt to manage expectations for a non-functional product in advance.  The real customer here isn't the person paying $20,000.  The real customer is a Venture Capital fund.  This "launch" is nothing more than expensive theater designed to prove two things to investors:  1. "A market exists": "Look, people are willing to pay $20,000! We've created demand!"   2. "We have a data pipeline": "Look, we have a 'social contract' to get the data that will someday let us build the real product."    These pre-orders aren't profit. They are leverage for negotiating the next, much larger, funding round. 1X isn't selling robots to consumers; they are selling equity to investors, using this raw prototype and its first customers as the primary argument for an inflated valuation.

That is the biggest issue I have with the term "AI".  It is a buzzword.  But, it is just more computing and information gathering than we have done in the past.  Yes, AI works when it is just gathering information from the web to give you an answer or other output.  But, in the real world, it takes millions of computations to just type a comment on youtube.  Any task has to be programmed/learned/repeated by an autonomous robot to be able to actually function in a way that is beneficial, not to mention any obstacles or unpredictability that can happen in the real world.  We are very far from actually living in the world of the "I, Robot" movie.

I'd think it's one of those "let's get rich as quickly as possible with this new mumbo-jumbo" and "get on the hype train" stuff. Yeah, you could release a product that's functional OR you could hype it a lot to get funding. I believe that's what both the Pin and the R1 tried to do. Maybe they got so overwhelmed in debt because of the product they're trying to release than they expected the hype to be enough for them not to have to worry about getting a finished product to the market. It's trying to cut your losses and hoping people will defend you for a mediocre product (which they will, surprisingly or unsurprisingly so) and hoping for the best. Because yeah, let's be honest, research and development for a new product/service costs A LOT, so maybe you want to start competing and getting the money you invested back right away, but it's just not a real possibility. I'm not saying that the HUGE corporations like Apple or Google aren't losing money when they screw-up, the difference is that they have such a variety or other products and services (and even fans) that will continue to support them when they do screw-up. And this guys are just trying, I'd say, to get the money they invested back ASAP since they don't have any other product or service that will act as a safety net for them. It doesn't make it right, though, but it's what I'd say is happening here.

Actually, going from VR human operated to the real world shouldn't be all that different than what AI web browsing is able to do. It just has to train on a lot of VR operated data (ocular tracking and what the human sees, the controller movements, time lag etc.). This is a bit different than what nvidea was doing to train robots in a virtual environment with physics. Both of these approaches can work together. Imo, this is extremely feasible. The hard part was getting it operational with VR like this.

Making a humanoid robot supposed to do everything is the most American way of dealing with the chores robot problem. You can see the same thing with Tesla self driving and the AGI and it's because of the current state of the investment system where the dream has to go on in order to keep the investors coming from day one. Ultra-capitalism is literally going too far because investors can't grasp the complexity of technical challenges and everyone suffer from this.  The solution, like AGI, like solving the transportation problem like the chores is efficient and specialized tools that can actually do the job.  Even assuming that the robot actually works as is today, how long do you think it can resist dishwasher soap, lint, dust, liquids and inevitably falling over or getting it's precious hands stepped on before they have to be maintained or replaced ? In which world does that economy work? Robotics are for specialized purposes and environments for a reason : they're crazy complicated and expansive to maintain they are quite literally the opposite of the requirements.   Also also, we still haven't figured out how to mimic the energy density and precision of actual muscle, especially not at speed. And no amount of AI is fixing that.

To me it seems a better method for autonomous training for this robot is to train it on the task you want it to do.  For example, you set it in a "Learn Mode" at the area you want a task done (e.g. folding laundry), then you show it how you want your laundry folded, and where each article of clothing is designated for.  After which you set it to "Validate", and it repeats the action, to confirm it is to your satisfaction.  After that, then you set it in back in to normal mode and set the days and times you want the tasks completed, and go about your day.  Really cool concept, but still a long way to go, as you said.

The reason it's taking so long is cause they're slow training it, in real life, Other humanoid companies have trained thousands of hours very quickly in simulated environments that match real life areas and homes. So they can train very quickly as the simulation time can be increased, then when put in the humanoid body all those skills are slowed to real time, making them able to do things quickly and instantly with self correcting in the process, but thousands of hours in real life time takes an extremely long time even if the skills are spread across multiple robots. Hot take: 1X's strategy is a winning strategy in my opinion. There's a concept in business called Business Offer Shadow Testing, which basically involves companies allowing potential customers to preorder a non-finished product in order to understand whether or not people are remotely interested in the product. If you get good engagement from preorders, you know you're on to something, but if not, don't spend more resources on a completely finished product that nobody is going to use. The bottom line is: create an Minimum Viable Product, showcase it, allow preorders, and choose to continue or not depending on engagement. That is the safest way to launch a new product/service and it's been a successful business strategy for decades.

â€‹Â @Andy1341000Â The reality is object recognition has been a huge issue in AI research for a long while. Â @Andy1341000Â   " the big caveat is just human intervention" no, the big caveat is that even the best of the best robots manufacturers demos still 1 out of 10 times in best case scenarios.  Robots are awesome and reliable in controlled industrial environments, because sensors and routines are great for controlled industrial environments. The Artificial Intelligence (AI) dilemma mirrors the chicken and egg paradox: for AI to evolve, it needs training data, yet without that initial training, it cannot progress. Elon Musk and Tesla have already demonstrated the invaluable nature of this process. However, widespread suspicion of AI, while partially valid, could carry a high cost. While the West debates and hesitates, China is developing at full speed, as evidenced by their superior robotics. Our aversion and slowness risk losing the technological lead to them. Here in Brazil, we are accustomed to a long-term teaching process, similar to the years it takes to train a domestic worker to become reliableâ€”an analogy that partly resembles the time and effort needed to train AI. The crucial question is: are we willing to make the sacrifice to embrace and train AI, or will we allow China to fully dominate robotics technology? If nothing is done, the ultimate irony is that we will end up with Chinese robots inside our homes, and the public's suspicion will remain just as strong. Consider the consequences of inaction.

While we can all agree that AI itself is not quite there yet; you have to admit, the advances in non-autonomous robotics has been incredible. We're reaching a point where likely the first humans on Mars will likely still never actually go outside for regular tasks but instead remote-control various robots instead, Underwater welding could very easily become a remotely controlled task, and potentially no one will ever have to step foot in a diving bell ever again. Nuclear powerplants and hazardous laboratory environments can be operated by remote controlled avatars, etc etc, and from what I've seen, a decent amount of that is already here. The problem is people are far too focused on the autonamous nature of robots,  because they want an automated servant, but we're really over-looking the potential of remote-controlled robotics. I know I'd love to step into a suit and control a droid, handling things that would most certainly fatally poison me. I mean, hell, some people are still trying to figure out create mecha-suits, which is sick. Screw the AI crap, I want to control a robot body.

I think you've missed a massive and possibly scariest point of this... the training remote controllers aren't going to be some tech nerds, they're going to be from lower-income countries, it's going to be a proxy Asian/African maid without the hassle of providing visas, accommodation, living wage, language barrier etc.  There are going to be people in Vietnam, Phillipines, Indonesia, etc.  being told they can receive a headset and work from home, and they're going to spend their days on a one-way video call cleaning a very wealthy person's home remotely on a day-rate somewhere below their country's extremely low minimum-wage.  Every time the hardware fails a task,  the remote controller will be held responsible and have their pay docked from some contract they don't understand, and when they eventually realize this job is garbage, they'll give up, but the company won't care, they already got their data.  The remote controller will be training an algorithm to replace themselves later on so they never have any path to growth, really the opposite.   It's going to be a proxy maid service where you never have to look your employee in the eye, never have to hear them ask for a day off or build any kind of connection.  It's a pretty sick dystopia and the really gross part is that those working on this project will already be planning this and are fully aware of the consequences, risks and effects it will have on people and societies and they are choosing to go ahead with it anyway.

You know whatâ€™s wrong with your video? Itâ€™s that youâ€™ve probably never used a teletext system, or a cassette tape recorder to save hours of typing, or even initiated the loading of a game and waited several minutes for it to be transferred into the memory of an 8-bit microcomputer â€” just to play for a few hours and repeat the whole process again the next day. Youâ€™ve never had to use your imagination to look at a square pixel on a TV screen and believe it was a ball or a car.  This lack of experience with technology in its most rudimentary forms hinders your ability to envision what it might become. Belonging to a generation that lives in constant anxiety and is spoiled by having everything instantly available weakens your capacity to analyze things deeply, without falling into the trap of superficial judgments like â€œthis is goodâ€ or â€œthis is worthless.â€

From what I gathered - the whole point of even selling this robot IS to get from having to be teleoperated by a Human to becoming automated by learning from the Human Operator how to do those tasks. It's going to - at least - take 5 years of it operating to get to that level. So basically, this thing as it's shown to do in the video isn't to come until around 2030 and beyond. If Neuro takes over the operations of the Human Teleoperator - it can lead to Virtual AIs entering to Physical Bodies and becoming their own Sentient Beings in the future. Being able to grab a cup and hold it with just enough force to not let it slip while also not crushing it is actually an immensely difficult robotics problem. Our brains do it effortlessly, with tiny sensors in our fingers that can detect microscopic deltas of slippage of an object from our hand which lets us adjust the grip force (try it out by feeling a cup slipping from your hand as you relax your grip, and how intuitively your brain sends a signal to increase the grip force). Once a robot can pick up objects without crushing them or letting them slip out of it's hand it can quickly become useful for many tasks.

there's another important thing forgotten here - the ai chips needed to run this, cost around $40,000 (4xRTX PRO 6000 or 4xh100s) and unlike LLMs, there's no downtime for them, since the sensors dont just get turned off. And better yet - the chips have a lifetime expectancy of 3 continuous years. <- this is already for a "small" model.   There's always the hope of being able to make a cheaper to run AI - but as proven by LLMs, Image generators, and video generators - the smaller the model, the significantly worse it gets. and for "carrying glass" you can't accept a 30% success rate. even the $40k will only hit a success rate of 90% for the first few years. (so every 10th time they carry glass it breaks?).   They can claim it will run via the cloud - but that changes literally nothing in terms of chip costs and only makes it stop working if the internet ever blanks out. (meaning they'll just "discontinue" the robot after a few years - since running it will either be trash or too expensive.) - A machine learning engineer      More numbers:   this requires about 16000tflops and 400gb vram to operate.   teslas first original "full self driving" had 0.6tflops built into their car - which is why it was phenomenally too weak to process the data.

"...theoretically this is what we want AI to do, right?  It's not just AI generated videos and slop... we want it to be doing actually productive stuff..."  Theoretically, yes, agreed.  However, the issue is that someone is going to be making either $500/month per robot or a lump sum of $20k each on these things without proving they can actually do anything productive while consumers do the beta testing they should be doing before releasing it, or proving that the business will last long enough for the machines to 'learn' how to do what they're selling.  The promise of an all automated future, in my eyes, is that things will get less expensive as we scale these up, not easier on humans or less onerous, I focus almost exclusively on price.  The price of nothing is going down lately.  It's all going up, which you could argue has more to do with other factors, but I've yet to see someone actually be able to make their products cheaper when incorporating this exciting new technology... it just feels like something else to spend billions on instead of, well, people. Interestingly what it actually is is quite impressive and if they marketed it as a sort of remote operation safety device that would be really cool. It's also very impressive Robotics and while I don't love the look of the cloth exterior I think it's much more approachable than the shiny plastic and metal robots we've seen from other companies. All in all the hardware seems pretty great and I can actually come up with useful potential applications even for remote controlling it. I suspect that the remote operation is currently being used for training purposes if they are training a model to emulate these human movements they would need the training data from having actual humans inputting that movement so that actually makes a whole lot of sense it's just a question of whether or not they can actually deliver on that anytime in a reasonable future and with her not it makes any sense to give them your money now for that promise. Much like Tesla's self-driving technology it is necessary to have an immense amount of data on actual human operation in order to train an artificial intelligence and I don't actually think that there's a better way to do that than this sort of remote operation or perhaps motion capture but either one would require an actual human to perform these actions over and over and over. But also much like Tesla it seems very unlikely that they will have a fully operational housekeeping model in a realistic time period and any promise of such is dubious at best.

A lot of those "autonomous" robot food delivery pod bots have a similar issue. While they can navigate a lot of stuff, notice when they come to crosswalks. Many of them pause. That's not them thinking. That's often (at least in the ones that I have seen and investigated) them waiting for remote operator take over to have them remotely driven across streets and crosswalks when it is safe.

As someone that has wanted this reality since childhood I get your skepticism. But here is the other side of the thoughts from someone trying to justify a reservation. They have the hardware working which is such a massive part of this. They have the operators training these things daily and probably have a decent idea on how quickly they can master these tasks and have them be completed baseline. If they are advertising the capabilities they are training today they are likely confident they will deliver in the 2026 tomorrow. With three kids and two dogs, this list of tasks isn't just a few hours a week saved. Its lifechanging. A robot cleaning up after kids while I'm at work is a dream. Why do we want to make more money or why do we save for a car? We want convenience and a better quality of life. Start adding up costs for a house keeper and the added convenience of living with you and its more compelling. Its also more of a comparable on the privacy level the experts would invade. As for the expert operation, its definitely a privacy concern. I would personally require the ability to have my own VR  headset to train my robot special tasks. The expert should be fallback.

Medication? Never. Cooking/heating things? Never. Let it vacuum, clean dishes, tidy up, water plants, fold clothes, organize stuff, the menial stuff -- just never trust it with anything that your life or safety depends on.Â   But then again, we know that the average person has no sense of self-preservation and is too stupid to keep that in mind, and we'll see people dying because of this.

NEO is a humanoid robot marketed as an autonomous home assistant capable of chores like folding laundry and washing dishes, but its real functionality is mostly human-controlled via teleoperation. Only two simple autonomous actions have been shown, highlighting the gap between its marketing and reality. At $20,000 or $500/month, NEO is still in a beta phaseâ€”early adopters are effectively training the AI, much like Teslaâ€™s data-driven approach to self-driving. Privacy, safety, and usability issues remain major hurdles, and while the vision is promising, true autonomy and mainstream adoption are still years away.

this is all just a new variation on an old theme of rolling out something long before it's ready sometimes to simply sow fear, uncertainty and doubt into competitors in the space. Makes it harder for other companies that don't show off this type of fake AI to raise funds. I saw a lot of this in the 1990s in the computer industry where companies even like Microsoft would fake announcements of products or technology that they clearly did not have ready for production in order to show that they were working on it and that they were either at parity or advanced from competition. like the person actually controlling the robot throughout the demonstration. I was once told by the person who actually did it that a product release demonstration was actually someone under the podium controlling the output on the screen. there never was anything like the output they were showing to the press in its capabilities at that moment in time, but the press bought it. Should it be illegal to do that absolutely it probably is.

The biggest Issue I have is folding clothes. Putting things in and out of the dishwasher is relatively easy compared to that. Yes the objects are brittle. But the object is one solid object. For clothing - not only has the robot to touch and hold the fabric but if it wants to do it at a reasonable pace, it needs to run a cloth simulation within, to predict how the fabric is going to move, to then inform the control systems that run its motors. It adds a huge computational cost into the feedback loop that a robotics system is and it is an even harder challenge to do that in a mobile platform with limited battery life.   Iâ€˜m curious if for rich people, itâ€™s becoming a common thing to have a DGX200 Rack in their basement, a wifi that is capable of handling multiple high resolution camera streams to do the simulation, path planning, object recognition, â€¦ externally so the battery of the robot can be used to do mechanical labor, not computation.

I think one of the things that a lot of people may not realize is how much we still rely on movements from chores to maintain a certain amount of mobility, especially people that aren't sports inclined or don't like going to the gym. We've already outsourced so much of our movement as a culture: we no longer have to grow our own food, retrieve our own water, walk to get places, etc. And sure, that is wonderful on a lot of levels. Division of labor is great and technology has allowed a lot of advancements to happen with science. But unless you have a solid plan for how you're going to get your mobility and movement needs daily, you'll likely lose even more mobility than you have now. I mean, just look at already how many of us have chronic pain earlier and earlier in life from lack of movement and spending too much time on screens.   I'm not trying to be pessimistic. Very few people enjoy doing chores. But this could be another case of "wow this is such a great thing we're doing! look at all this extra time I have!" but not really thinking clearly or thoroughly about all the second and third order effects it has.

1. Compatibility with the human world  Our entire environment â€” tools, buildings, stairs, cars, door handles, keyboards â€” is designed for human bodies. A robot thatâ€™s roughly our shape (two arms, two legs, similar height) can:  Use the same tools and machines we use  Walk through human-designed spaces  Drive vehicles, carry boxes, open doors, etc. This makes humanoid robots more universally useful than machines designed for a single task.  ğŸ¤ 2. Ease of social interaction  Humans instinctively read body language, facial expressions, and gestures. A human-shaped robot can:  Communicate naturally (through facial expressions, hand motions, posture)  Build trust more easily  Work better as a helper, teacher, caregiver, or companion Thatâ€™s why robots designed for social or service roles â€” like hospital assistants or customer greeters â€” are often made to look and move somewhat human-like.  ğŸ§© 3. Research into intelligence and embodiment  Building human-like robots helps scientists understand us. When researchers try to make machines walk, balance, perceive, and manipulate like humans, they uncover new insights into:  Neuroscience and motor control  Perception and coordination  Learning and cognition  Humanoid robotics is as much a scientific experiment about human intelligence and body design as it is about practical applications.  ğŸ’¡ 4. Cultural and emotional appeal  Humans are storytellers â€” weâ€™ve dreamed about mechanical people for centuries (from ancient myths to modern sci-fi). Making robots that resemble us satisfies a deep creative and philosophical urge to â€œmirror ourselvesâ€ in our inventions.

TL;DR ğŸ¤–   The NEO humanoid robot is heavily hyped but currently relies on remote human control, showing a large gap between promise and reality common in early AI products.  ğŸ¤– Key Points   - NEO promises to autonomously handle chores but is mostly teleoperated today.   - Pre-orders start at $20,000 or $500/month, with limited real autonomous features.   - There is a significant gap between current capabilities and marketing hype, a common AI product issue.   - True autonomy needs extensive AI training and real-world data, similar to Tesla's gradual self-driving rollout.   - Early adopters will serve as beta testers, facing privacy concerns and imperfect performance as the tech evolves. Watched a really good video by another dude that summed up the current issues with "AI" perfectly; the current bet is spending a lot on increasing memory, but not really spending more on "AI" actually learning things.   If anyone's paid attention to the space, AI as it exists today is only really powerful as the the quality and the amount of data that you provide over to it. Your models out in ChatGPT or whatever that aren't local will generally perform better than anything you can get locally because they're just feeding more powerful hardware along with more data to generate better results to whatever you prompt over to it. If we're talking about getting better AI long term though, it also should be able to operate with a limited memory to learn what it needs to know then perform based on what it learns.  A giant robot like this is never going to have infinite memory. That is objectively impossible to achieve, no matter whos backing the project. For it to function in the way you're showing, it would have to be able to have some capacity to be able to learn so it can perform whatever tasks your asking it to do. If it's not a scam, then I'm almost certain this is likely going to be a giant waste of metal, and would bankrupt the company if it actually did exist because it'd need to be fed continuous data by said company that likely cannot afford that data.

Â @benstanfill363Â  Regarding the risks, it could potentially... ... burn your house to the ground by e.g. knocking a candle over, leaving the oven on, etc. ... kill or disable a toddler by stepping onto him, giving him access to dangerous things, etc. ... poke someone's eye out with its fingers, stab them (accidentally) when handling a knife, etc. ... and more. One thing you learn when programming is to not assume that a machine has the situational awareness an adult has and if it hasn't been told to not put a bowling ball on a shelf over a newborn baby, chances are that it eventually will.  Now to the implementation part: I'm not an expert on these things either but a car essentially can turn left and right, brake and accelerate. Sure, the environment can do lots of unpredictable things very fast but the amount of possible reactions of the car is rather small. My understanding is that full self driving is mainly limited by ethics (giving a machine that kind of power) and sensory issues/edge cases (the car can't see a threat or doesn't know how to respond to it). Computers these days are extremely fast compared to humans at such things so time shouldn't be an issue once it sees something, afaik. Now compare that to the immense amount of movements a human hand (or its robotic knock-off) has to be able to perform to extreme levels of precision just to pick up, say, a CD vs a mug vs a pillow vs a cat vs a chair and I can absolutely see how it is more difficult to do that than to teach a car how to drive safely. But, again, this is just what my limited knowledge of the matter leads me to conclude.

Â @seba5167Â  Yes, you are correct in your points. Another point i would like to highlight is computation. All these fancy AI stuff needs massive amounts of compute. you can either do all this in the cloud (then you are dependent on wifi and support, and data security is a nightmare) or you can do it on the robot/car itself. but a capable gpu is heavy and sucks a LOT of energy, especially on an entity that needs energy to move around or even stand (such as an humanoid robot). a car has a bigger battery and weighs a ton anyway, so it does not matter too much (although heavy gpu workloads will have a noticeable impact on milage), but for a robot thats a whole other problem.

I totally agree with AI companies and their exaggerated adverts, AI is good at some things even brilliant, but it is far from what companies promised.  This incident is indeed very striking. The reason people don't trust companies today is based on misleading statements like this. In the past, such "white lies" were told about the cereal you bought - it contains all the vitamins, it's very beneficial for your health etc. Now these "white lies" have gone far beyond being harmless advertising nonsense, in fact they've become so common, so far that it's become impossible to see anything different. Advertising has shifted from presenting the product's strengths and persuading the consumer, to deceiving the consumer with non-existent promises without facing legal problems.  Unfortunately, when making profit becomes the only goal, companies, products, and their communication have all turned into hollow, pathetic shells.

On the other hand, I would highly consider opening my home to such a robot to let it train as I have minimal privacy issues and no dependents at present, but if I had a family or things that I would actively care about beyond locking my bedroom door when I sleep, I would be far more hesitant. Roads are easier IMO because there's a smaller range of variables and ultimately a much more restricted "goal" - what a car has to do in normal operation is very well defined and where it has to do it is usually fairly well defined (within an area, even an entire country, most roads are quite standardised - personally I think it'll be quite a while, if ever, before driverless cars can operate reliably on e.g. unmarked dirt tracks but "main" roads all have a lot more in common).   Every house is different though (and I don't agree they're as static in functional terms as you suggest - bags/shoes/toys on the floor, pets/kids/adults moving around, drawers and doors open/closed/ajar etc. It's arguably less dynamic, sure BUT in more potential ways during normal operation. Obstructions "just appearing" in a house is the norm rather than the exception in other words). Plus, a car "only" has to avoid ALL collisions - road itself aside, you basically never want a car to physically interact with anything - whereas a household robot actually must "collide" with numerous objects - doors, drawers, dishes etc. - in order to work BUT in a controlled way and crucially also never collide with other objects like pets, kids etc. Which is inherently more complex.

Guys, PhD in AI & Robotics here: - Marquees isn't wrong, BUT: the teloperation thing is low key a genius idea, and here's why. While it's true that full autonomy in unstructured environments is very much on going research and an open problem, (1) we are making tremendous steps in that direction, (2) AI for robotics is ALREADY capable of achieving full autonomous behavior in ONE PARTICULAR TASK AND SETTING WITH JUST 5-10 DEMONSTRATIONS OF THAT TASK. Let that sink in. This really means that you could have it teleoperated for a week or two, and then it'll be adapting already to whatever chores and house you have. TLDR: don't let the teleoperation side fool you. That's just the beginning of it getting autonomous in the near future

Capitalizing off what you said about Tesla; It's actually much more important than that. A 2020 Tesla Model 3 has HW3 self-driving, with a supposed HW4 upgrade if HW3 can't reach the expectations of the future that Tesla promised. It would absolutely impale them if they went back on that promise, so it's almost a sure thing that if you buy the car, you'll get the full FSD experience someday.  The difference between this 1X robot, and a car, is that even without the AI features.. The Tesla still works. And they both cost about the same price; $20,000. This alone makes the robot just not warrantable; you're solely dependent off experimental variables instead of having a backup reliable experience anyways to make it still kinda worth it.   I can see the struggles for 1X considering they're competing in a market that strictly involves data to be acquired to tune the best robot. It's like Tesla dominating the self-driving market since they're one of the few (especially in the US and UK) that actually have their foot in the door.  They won't be able to compete if another competitor starts shipping quicker than they do.. especially at a similar or cheaper price.

No no no no. Product testing *IS NOT A 21ST CENTURY, "AI new"  PROBLEM**. No. What you are *actually seeing is the complete collapse in law enforcement. It has never been OK to test you products on the general public -- there are actual laws against that. but somehow, we *allow* these particular companies to test their products on the general public.  in the past, companies *PAY* good money to test their products well, they *PAY* people to do training, experiments, etc. We historically call this R&D.   No No no. Do not try to explain this as a new phenomenon. No AI is not some unique exception because it needs data. ALL. PRODUCT. TESTING. NEEDS. DATA. Since forever. Please get some perspective and dont start drifting into the hype. Clearly you see something wrong here too, but the only reason this is happening is because our laws are actively not being enforced and our leaders do not know what 21st century snake oil looks like.

14:05 exactly. Why even make them humanoid? It's needlessly complex and one day will be pointless anyway. Imagine every house has one, suddenly humans don't need to operate vacuums. The reason vacuums are shaped and function the way they do is because they're meant for humans to use. But in the future it'll be only robots operating them. So why make vacuums human friendly shapes? Then there's no need to make either the vacuum or robot human shaped eventually. Fun fact, we already have roombas. It'll come full circle. Just automate the objects, it's easier and we can basically already do it.

To answer your question @13:00, I doubt it. How many people that CAN spend $20K on a robot to do laundry, that consider their time more lucrative if spent doing other things, don't already have someone they pay to do this in their home, much faster, and better? would 4 hours of uptime (and however long it takes it to charge) even be enough time to do all the things they need it to do? Would they have to buy multiple to get the same amount of work done? I just don't see the problem this is actually solving without raising a ton of questions that it can't answer. For example, they say NEO won't through paper on the stove, but what actually stops it from doing that? And not like, is it going to kill us on purpose, but like, we already know "guard rails" in AI don't do anything, so what makes this different?

Why do these need legs? Tread systems can go up stairs. If its just going to be in your home on nice flat ground, why have the complexity of walking upright in your home robot? Unironically make it like Rosy from the Jetsons. Not exactly of course, but the concept of wheels and a humanoid torso and arms. Then give it a face that is clearly just a robot and not a creepy felt face that feels like its trying to blend in to lull you into a false sense of security.

I believe humanoid robots will be a huge societal shift, much like self-driving cars will be someday. My imagined timeline for self-driving cars is that they are generally acceptable by 2030, and by 2035 everyone will expect their next car to be good at self-driving, and by 2040 a minority of people will want to drive a car most of the time.  For humanoid robots, I think it's probably a good 5 or 10 years behind that timeline, but it could be quicker, it depends how well this one goes. By 2030 they are a thing that some people have, 2035 everyone is kind of half in the market for them, 2040 people plan around buying them, and by 2045 they are pretty common. Ironically (if that's the right term here), self-driving cars will probably change how we even own cars, with either only one per household, or none for most people, and so the money people traditionally would put towards car ownership will go towards Household Humanoid Robots (H3Rs?).

Humanoid robot companies focussing on the "household industry" is quite challenging due to, as Marques mentioned, various nuanced differences between chores, between house layout, between items in the house. This is why many robotic startups (which has raised tons of $ and have very high valuations) such as Figure AI, Apptronik, Agility Robotics are focussing at the automotive/manufacturing industry as one of the primary use cases due to high-repeatability of tasks and tasks of various complexities. Also, the fact that many blue-collared workers are retiring, and younger people are not interested in the blue collared environment as much as they used to years ago. Our population is ageing, and its a perfect area for humanoids, but that will probably come later.  Though Figure AI is also focussing on household work, they have a big partnership with BMW, and they have deployed robots in their Chattanooga manufacturing plant. Same with Apptronik, a big partnership with Mercedes-Benz. UBTech has deployed humanoids in Zeekr plant in China (China is a lot ahead in this area that USA is).

Needs 2 or 3 overseers for every remote operator.  Otherwise, the remote operators can act badly, or be easily conpromised by nearby bad actors.  "You're piloting a robot in a rich person's house? Multiple overseers needed to reduce the chance of a successful bribe when the evil or hijacked operator has the robot write out "be cool overseer, and I will give you a cut of he theft proceeds." Big bounty for the overseer whenever an overseer turns in an operator for bad behavior. 10:00 The dramatic difference between autonomy data gathering in cars versus chore robots is for the car, if you have to take over the car is still a 100% functional car, still very efficient in completing the task, without any loss of productivity.   For the chore robot to learn in an unobtrusive fashion (even ignoring all privacy concerns), you'd want something equivalent to the "driver seat" that still lets you get your task done, otherwise it's quicker to just do it yourself without training. I'm not sure how they'll bridge this "training effort gap" for chore robots. They really would need a fleet of hundreds-of-thousands of people doing chores, but capturing that kinematic data in an unobtrusive way is tricky.

I don't think the gap is massive between a human controlled robot and an autonomous one. They have already built the mechanisms so that the robot can stand, that it can move, pick up and put down, as well as balance. That it can accept inputs which drive locomotion. Everything is already there for the robot to operate autonomously, what is required is a software update to drive it autonomously. I don't know how far the gap is for the AI to do things all on it's own. But I know all AI training models make massive amounts of progress just within the first year.

I think making the telepresence robot available surruptitiously like this will damage trust that makes people mistrust even if/when it is actually autonomous. I think this behavior can be seen mainly (I say mainly because there are notable exceptions) from companies that are too small and too poor for their dreams. They need to make the product buyable in an unfinished state because they simply run out of money to develop it further, to actually finish it. The simple answer behind all of this is ... they need money and a leg up.  On the money front, their series B fundraising round raised $100M - compare that to their leading US rivals: Figure, who most recently raised $1B or Tesla, which can throw money at it all day.  Cybertruck had 2M preorders, if they got even 5% of that they would have an additional $20M (a full 1/6th of their funds coming from that preorder funds) of capital to throw at AI training and manufacturing. More importantly it would increase their valuation for a series C round.  Figure is primarily focused on industry (with long term goals for in home) and already has commercial customers (hence $1B series C at a $39B valuation) but 1X is focusing solely on the home with no plans for industry - so they have to acquire some retail customers going into their series C if they're going to raise the kind of capital they need.  On the leg up aspect, Tesla has huge amounts of self-driving data they're basing their AI on, they've repeatedly said "Optimus thinks its a car". Figure is collecting industrial data at BMW and (likely) UPS. They also recently announced that their inhouse AI implementation (helix) is improving much faster than their previous version (an Openai based implementation) and they are moving up their timeline for in home applications by 2 years - to facilitate this they've entered into a partnership with Brookfield to utilize their portfolio of 100,000 residential units to get a large diverse data set of training environments.  1X only started limited testing in a few employee's homes this year - that's the entirety of their training data. They need to get the robot out there to collect more data or they're going to get scooped on the home market by Figure.   TLDR: Its shitty that their promo video overhypes what the robot can currently do and undersells just how often you will likely be using "expert mode" in the first few years of ownership - but if the company wants to survive, the landscape is moving quickly enough that this really is their only viable path foreword (unless they pivoted to commercial/industry which would likely require significant redesign to make the robot stronger/ more precise).

I think you missed the point... It may seem far fetch, but the reason this is closer than never is that it has been developed a AI that allows robots to simulate tasks, so it basically can dream it's doing the chores from its own perspective, and the more AI video generation physics improves, more realistic it becomes, so when it does it for real, it actually succeeds. For the first time ever, we don't need to train robots in real time, they can train themselves in a pace faster than reality, without actual physical interaction. The experiments started from making AI learn how to play Minecraft by imagining it, so it has a bit of actual training, but it learns to react to many different scenarios by just 'imagining' it beforehand. This has been tested for robot arms and it worked pretty well, pretty close to ground truth!

Iâ€™m gonna hazard a few guesses here so hear me out.  First is this aims to replace housekeepers with robots that are controlled remotely by cheap remote housekeepers, allowing them to do multiple 4 hour (battery life) robots a day. Probably in call center type facilities. These control centers (con centers if you will) will also be a way to gather data, from the people working there about how humans move and solve these problems. Also just for a second picture what those centers would likely look like, warehouses of cubicles of people in vr doing housework remotely. A job that currently would face little to no oversight or regulation.  Additionally, think of the security issues, anyone who can afford this is unlikely to want to let an unknowable stranger or faceless mass of strangers learn the ins and outs of their properties, security, and life schedule, not even to mention any private conversations, meetings, or documents.  From a social and economic point of view, if the workers are paid very little (which is almost always the case in these matters) but they have incredibly valuable information about successful wealthy people (security vulnerabilities, blackmail, or even insider trading info) then they are gonna sell it. And thatâ€™s not even to say they canâ€™t be paid to fabricate incriminating or damaging material with their access.  I think itâ€™s worth noting that the company is actually pretty transparent about the purpose of their robots being data gathering and building a big ol database of homes and actions etc. Which they claim is to build a better product. But who knows if they will utilise that data to let companies advertise ultra specifically, or let insurers gain unfettered access to your life, or any other number of things. And hell even if 1x tech donâ€™t do that, what happens if they go bust? That data wonâ€™t just disappear.

Even with progress in some years, beyond knowing shapes and colours for dishes, it has to know which dishes in the sink can't go in the dishwasher. It has to know which garments, despite their color, go on cold cycle versus hot cycle. It would have to know which clothes need folding for the drawers and which shirts to hang in the closet, as well as where to put them. It has to know which vacuum head to switch to for rugs versus which one to use for hardwood. I think products like these are great on paper but for some reason I can't help but feel that after doing your own cleaning for a substantial amount of time, whether there can ever be enough trust in autonomous devices to leave us just as satisfied. The project scope of a fully autonomous robot that is able to handle an infinite number of random situations is completely unrealistic. Aside from the hilariously hopeless task of attempting to replicate the complex kinematics of the human body, the artificial intelligence aspects of the project seem doomed from the start. A much more realistic expectation is for the user to train the robot based on their unique environment and task parameters, such as defining where specific areas/objects are in the house and establishing tasks manually with predictable/consistent parameters (i.e. store medicine in a specific spot, and the robot should remind the user to place items in the same spot for next time).

buying a product on the future promise?  Short answer: usually noâ€”unless the â€œpromiseâ€ is nailed down in writing.  Quick checklist:  Contract, not vibes: future features, dates, and remedies spelled out in the order or SLA.  Escape hatch: clear refund/return policy if the promise slips.  Teeth: penalties, discounts, or extended warranty if deadlines are missed.  Proof: public roadmap with dated milestones + a track record of shipping on time.  Custody of cash: pay on delivery or milestone-based; avoid paying 100% upfront.  Ownership now: is the product useful today without the future stuff? If not, itâ€™s a preorder/crowdfund risk.  Support & updates: who maintains it, how long, and what happens if the company folds?  Red flags: â€œcoming soonâ€ for >12 months, shifting ETAs, no demo, no references, aggressive urgency/discounts.  Simple rule: If the promise is critical â†’ require dates + remedies in writing. If the promise is nice-to-have â†’ buy only if todayâ€™s version already delivers value.  â€œBefore purchasing, please confirm in writing: (1) the specific features coming, (2) delivery dates, (3) what Iâ€™m entitled to if dates slip (refund/credit/extended warranty), and (4) whether updates are included in the price. Thanks.â€  When in doubt, treat it like a preorder: cap your risk, pay later, or wait until it ships.

I have a robot that cleans my home. Had it for years now, I call her Milly.   She has a voice but I disabled that shortly after buying. Itâ€™s mainly for informing me of any issues she might run into while cleaning. Like if she tripped down the stairs and need help or when she needs cleaning done to herself.   She can contact me via an app on my phone but I disabled her internet connection right at the start.  She has sufficient eyesight to distinguish light from dark and can roughly identify certain shapes. But she mostly navigates by touch and reflected infrared, using a memorised map of the interior layout of my apartment.  She probably knows my schedule because she only works when Iâ€™m not home, but I donâ€™t think she really understands what a schedule is nor can she sense whether Iâ€™m home or not, as she cannot distinguish between a human leg and a table leg.   She can become quite territorial if Iâ€™m in her way when sheâ€™s cleaning, but she doesnâ€™t weigh very much and is mostly plastic, so a swift kick in the face is all it takes to overpower her.   She looks nothing like any human Iâ€™ve ever seen. Small, flat, round, with 2 large outboard rubber wheels on suspension and a single front wheel on a free rotating caster.   She mostly require no special care. Just a few filters every now and then a proper cleaning about every second month.  And only cleans floors. Vacuum, sweep, dust. She has extra mopping attachments but I couldnâ€™t be bothered to fit them.   Iâ€™m disappointed to see this new much more advanced robot is less capable than my old basic one. I guess the technology has some way to go still.

Hello Marques, I see things a bit differently. You said Neo needs to learn all objects in all variations within the household to recognize them. And you brought up Tesla, with over a decade of experience. It's true that, at the moment, the robot can't do much independently. But since the beginnings of Tesla, there's been a huge leap in IT development: LLMs and VLMs. If you ask Google Lens what it sees, it practically makes no mistakes. It recognizes a crumpled sock on the floor. And if you ask an LLM where the sock belongs, it definitely won't suggest the refrigerator, but the washing machine. A robot can now know very precisely what it needs to do. And that's the point where we are today. It was completely different two years ago. The only (and huge) gap is still the robot's movement and proper grasping, etc. But worldwide, hundreds of companies and research groups are working on exactly this problem, so it won't take many more years. So if Neo has excellent hardware, including sensors and computing power, and the company guarantees years of updates, then Iâ€™d happily watch him grow up. And those are the real questions you should be asking the developers.

On one hand I can see how a teleoperated robot cleaning and doing chores every day in my house could be nice, especially at the right price point (plus maybe you could split the cost with 3 to 5 neighbors and share it). But I could also see a scenario where teleoperators gather info about people and sell it to criminals, they would know where everything is in the houses, could potentially steal sensitive financial info or passwords, they know when you are usually not home, can alert criminals when house is unoccupied, etc. They could record audio and video and use it for blackmail.

Â @NachoshitÂ  Yeah, unfortunately, that usualy means the companies absolve themselves of any responsibility of damages caused by these products and enforce an arbitrage clause.   This of course depends on the legal environment, it's easier to do this in US than in EU or Australia, but a contract usualy favours the selling business rather than the customer unless there is an existing regulation in place (which there isn't for AI producs) or it's a B2B contract, where both sides have similiar negotiating power.

Â @Coffee-7993Â  Microsoft/windows/Google PCs, Tesla, GM, VW, Chinse vehicle manufacturers should have more than enough computing capacity to do local infrence, yet they all gather obscene amount of data. That gap you explained between what it can do now and what it is envisioned to do in the future, although massive for an average human to learn in a reasonable amount of time, is nothing for AI controlled robots. Here is why; let 's assume 10 thousand of such robots are sold. Every day each one of the robots will learn something. Say, for example, one robot in one day learn that  when it opens the door, if the knob looks round it has to turn it clockwise and if it is like a handle it has to hold it differently and do another motion. Something so small. This knowledge will be instantly uploaded the next day for all the robots who didn't have the experience. In other words, each robot, in 1 day will learn 10 thousand days of experience (collectively, all experiences in 1 day for 10 thousand robots). In one single day they will each have collective knowledge of 27 years of knowledge.  The gap will close so fast you wouldn't even realize it. They will be only limited by hardware.

I have first hand experience with this product (not this exact one because this is a newer iteration than what I saw), as I worked on a commercial for 1X two years ago. We went to their headquarters in Moss, Norway and shot on location. I got to witness its capabilities at that point in time, and to put it simple: seeing them open up for pre-orders already from next year for this product is something I did not expect. Based on what I saw back then, it would take a miracle to have that robot commercially ready within the next couple of years, heck even by the next decade and I am not exaggerating. It is by all means an extremely intriguing concept, but having pre-orders at this point in time is just a financial move with no delivery date attached for sure. I wish them all the best on the journey to develop this robot, but just as you reflect on here about the actual capabilities of the 1X, Marques, it is not even close at getting to the point where it is fully functional.

A remote driven Robot with part-time AI is IMHO the worst combination imaginable.  A remote controlled robot is much worse in doing stuff than what a autonomous robot can do. The dishwasher example is a good example: Remote controlled hands are VERY hard, while AI controlled hands pretty much work very well today. Also: AI that contains code that is "hand written" and not trained is bad. That's why Tesla is removing hand written code from their Self-Driving autonomous AI, because it is crippling the AI big time.  The other way around is perfectly fine: Have a AI driven robot; and only in exceptions allow a human to remote control it to help when it is stuck for example.

As a researcher working on how robots can learn from people and can be designed to give people more control (rather than taking over), Marques makes a really good point about how 1X is selling a promise, rather than a product. Training an autonomous robot to operate safely around people in homes requires a ton of data - and if only a limited set of people are willing to adopt Neo to schedule an operator and give data, how long will it be until the teleoperator is not needed anymore? It could be over a decade (see Tesla and how their promise of fully autonomous vehicles is going), which opens up crazy privacy and safety concerns. I'm curious to see how their product is adopted and comes along, but I bet these may just end up being a hardware tech novelty, not the robot chore assistant promised.

Things that could go wrong with a humanoid home-maker robot â€” covering technical, ethical, and social risks:  ğŸ§  1. Technical & Operational Failures Software glitches or bugs â€“ could cause incorrect or unpredictable actions (e.g., spilling boiling water or misplacing objects). Hardware malfunction â€“ motors, sensors, or joints may fail, leading to accidents or fire hazards. Navigation errors â€“ poor obstacle detection could make it bump into furniture, pets, or humans. Connectivity issues â€“ Wi-Fi or cloud disruptions might halt its operations or make it unresponsive. Battery or power failure â€“ could leave it stuck mid-task or cause electrical hazards.   ğŸ” 2. Privacy & Security Risks Data breaches â€“ cameras and microphones might record private moments, making homes vulnerable to hacking or surveillance. Unauthorized access â€“ hackers could remotely control the robot to spy, steal data, or cause harm. Voice command hijacking â€“ false or spoofed commands could trick the robot into unsafe actions.   âš™ 3. Safety & Physical Harm Injury risks â€“ if a robot misinterprets gestures or proximity, it might unintentionally hurt someone. Fire or gas leaks â€“ errors in handling appliances could lead to dangerous accidents. Failure to distinguish humans or pets â€“ could cause harm while cleaning or carrying objects.   ğŸ§© 4. Ethical & Social Concerns Job displacement â€“ widespread use might replace human domestic workers. Over-dependence â€“ people may lose essential life skills or motivation for chores. Emotional attachment â€“ users might form unhealthy relationships or expectations toward robots. Bias in algorithms â€“ if trained on flawed data, the robot may make unfair or inappropriate decisions.   ğŸ§° 5. Maintenance & Cost Issues High repair and upgrade costs â€“ specialized parts and technicians may be expensive. Obsolescence â€“ rapid tech evolution could render the robot outdated quickly. Software subscription locks â€“ companies might charge recurring fees to keep the robot functional.   âš– 6. Legal & Liability Issues Unclear accountability â€“ if the robot causes damage or injury, itâ€™s uncertain who bears responsibility â€” manufacturer, owner, or developer. Regulatory gaps â€“ laws may not yet cover autonomous domestic robots adequately.

I definitely see an opportunity here for a new product category. Maybe in the future, these companies could use cheap labor from poorer countries to handle housework, without actually letting a stranger into your home, by controlling where these remote workers can go and what they can do.   Itâ€™s kind of like an Uber model, where the company acts as an intermediary between the worker and the client. Then, eventually, robots might take over these tasks entirely, and the companies will let go of those workers too. Weâ€™re already seeing a similar pattern with AI: workers use AI tools long enough to train them, and then the companies replace the workers with the tools.   So I think the most interesting thing to pay attention to here is actually the workers controlling these robots, not the clients enjoying the services. ğŸ¤”

Robotics today lacks what most other domains do not, an abundance of data i.e., movements, doing specific tasks and experience random situations that require physical dexterity and cognitive ability. So a smart way to advance this domain would be: 1. Place robots in homes. They can be remotely operated by humans, FOR NOW. 2. Data is collected and robot learns as the human operators move the robot to do specific tasks. That's also called Imitation learning. 3. As the robot keeps receiving more data, it learns more tasks to do, ON ITS OWN. 4. Eventually with enough data experience, a robot can function in a typical home almost autonomously.  This also leads to a new job domain (for a while), "Humanoid Operator" or maybe a more clever title.

Once these robots are able to do just one or two tedious chores reliably, with minimal maintenance, they'll become extremely popular. They don't need to be fast either. They can be extremely slow.  If they spend 6-8 hours to do the dishes, but they do the dishes flawlessly and nothing else people will still pay a lot for them.  I see a lot of people being critical of humanoid robots and I see their point, but all our 'infrastructure' is built for humans to navigate. A humanoid robot can navigate our homes or offices, without having to rebuild or modify everything. It would probably be easier to build a dish washer robot that only excels at taking dishes in and out of the dishwasher, but a human robot could potentially do every chore a human can do decently at some point. And they don't need to be fast and efficient at it.  Once one of these humanoid robots can reliably do just a few chores these will have tremendous utility.

I'm regularly amazed at how biased you are towards Tesla... First: stating that their crappy auto drive leads in the auto industry is straight up laughable, but then making a parallel with what this company is doing with it's customers is just deceiving: when neo will mess up, he'll break a glass of two. Tesla is willing to kill people in order to actually being able to engineer their products and to sell more cars, which is straight up criminal and absolutely unacceptable, whereas neo will mess up a few tacky items in some rich guy's house. All the work that i see from these robots is ridiculous ! They cannot do anything proper ! To keep a household hygienic is a task that only humans can do the right way ! It is not just putting some pillows on the couch and getting the dishes into the kitchen. Cleaning an apartment means :   1 : remove the dust from the surfaces with a dust cloth. 2 : put all the things back to its original place where it belongs 3 : Put all the dishes CAREFULLY into the dishwasher, donÂ´t waste any space, put cleaner tabs inside and start the mashine  4 : use the vacuum cleaner and donÂ´t forget any space around the furniture ( put away cables or other stuff in the way ) 5 : wipe the floor with a damp cloth using some pressure to clean stains on the floor (  add cleaner to the water to desinfect the floor surface and replace the dirty water by fresh and clean water to keep the cleaning standard ) and open the windows for 10 minutes to get fresh air inside and watch carefully that nobody from outside jumps in through the windows and steals anything of value 6 : put the dirty clothes ( sorted by color and washing temperature ) into the washing mashine, put the right amount of washing powder and softener into the mashine and start it 7 : etc. 8 : etc. Not a single humanoid robot is capable to do these things like a human would do ! We are years away from such capabilities for robots ! Everyone who thinks different is naive !

No amount of training something that is not actually intelligent and canâ€™t think will ever be able to handle every possible situation. No matter what an â€œAIâ€ is trained for, it is still just a generative pre-trained transformer, which means it is taking a bunch of input and then picking the next thing it thinks it should do next - one thing, or one word, at a time. It may have a context window allowing it to â€œrememberâ€ for a little while, but that always has a limit. Sure it could save sets of tasks it can repeat,so long as new variables are not introduced. You get a new set of dishes that look a lot different from the old ones and maybe you are keeping the old ones and now the robot has to be trained a bunch to add that to itâ€™s dataset. And what happens if the dog stops in front of it and barks, or that cat jumps onto its shoulder or things like that?  So sure itâ€™s all fine for willing participants to help train these models, but we still have a pretty long way to go before truly autonomous robotic devices can really work. Never mind mass adoption.

Honest question. Specs say: 154 lbs lift, 55 lbs carry max capacity. Is that enough for it to have physical power to break, say, a finger or some other human bone? Can this be calculated? Or if it tries to hit you with full force, what would be the damage. Math people out there, thnx in advance.

Â @pffyespffÂ  Not a math person, but this is what I got from ChatGPT: Short answer: Maybe â€” but not just by squeezing.  A â€œ154 lb lift / 55 lb carryâ€ spec means about 686 N of steady force, which is below the ~1,500 N usually needed to break a finger bone. So a slow push probably wouldnâ€™t fracture anything.  But if the robot moves fast and hits you, itâ€™s different â€” even a 5 kg arm swinging at 3 m/s can deliver over 4,000 N, easily enough to break bones. The lift rating tells you static strength, not impact force.  So: safe to work near only if it has proper speed, force, and contact-safety limits (like cobots under ISO 10218 / 15066). Otherwise, a fast strike could definitely injure you.

I'm actually going to massively disagree that roads are inherently less complicated, than a house. While it's true that every house will be different, even in apartment complexes where all the units are the same, the furniture will differ in placement and type. It's also true that the house the robot operates in will mostly not change, but that isn't true for roads. Sure, the actual road stays largely the same for relatively long stretches of time, but traffic changes, kids run out into the road, trees fall, construction happens, weather changes, EMS/police can disturb the flow of traffic, etc. The self driving problem is hard because no road is the exact same two days in a row.  However, a house is. The residents of a home don't change that often, pets don't get swapped for new ones all the time, the dishes stay the same, the layout essentially never changes, etc. Don't get me wrong, houses aren't static, but they certainly vary dramatically less, than do roads.   I would argue a bot figuring out household chores is an order of magnitude easier, than self driving. Mostly because the vast majority of household tasks aren't life or death. If the clanker hangs up your boxers in the closet and folds up your blazer, then that's annoying, but not ultimately harmful. Sure, you mentioned meds for the elderly. That could well be life or death. There are tasks like that. Cooking or letting the dogs out the wrong door. Disposing of a project because the bot thought it was trash. Lots of things are high stakes, but there are far more  very low stakes tasks where a bot could mess up and everything would be fine.

So what this company should do, is to collaborate with universities and teaching hospitals and so on, and get grants for units to be built, to be remote controlled assistants in the homes of people that need assistance. That way they can get the training data they need. Most likely working side by side with a human, and probably remote controlled from a van outside the house, and with the robot transported in the van between assignments.   Buying one outright makes no sense, for those that subscribe, they can be fairly confident, that they will be among the first to have a household robot, even if it is remote controlled a lot of  the time, and at some point another company may be able to build one that is less reliant on remote controlled actions.   Regarding the humanoid shape. Unless you have several of specialized robots, the humanoid shape makes most sense. We have designed our life around humans, thus that makes the most sense as a general use robot. There is possibly an argument that having several of specialized robots would be cheaper, and more efficient than trying to design a humanoid shaped robot that can actually to all the tasks you want from it. But in terms of general usage robots, I cant think of any other robot shape that would not have drawbacks in too many areas, even if it would excel at some tasks.
